NN as universal approximator (L1, Aug 28 - L2, Aug 30)
  • Input (e.g. images) â black box â output (e.g. captions)
  • Connectionist machine - models of neurons functioning in humanâs brain
    • Opposed to Von Neumann machines ( processing unit â memory (program, data))
    • NN as a program = connection between units (also define memory)
  • The McCulloch & Pitts model (1943) - a logical calculus of the ideas immanent in nervous activities
    • can compose Boolean functions
    • can compose real-values functions
  • Hebbian learning â Fundamentally unstable
    • Stronger connections will enforce themselves
    • No notion of âcompetitionâ
    • No reduction in weights
    • Learning is unbounded
  • Rosenblattâs perceptron

    â provide a learning algorithm

    • Boolean tasks
    • Update the weights whenever the perceptron output is wrong
    • Proved convergence for linearly separable classes

Alan Turingâs Connectionist model (1948): Learnable networks that could potentially be trained to model any Boolean function

  • If neuron x repeatedly triggers neuron y, the synaptic knob connecting x to y gets larger.

Mathematically, wxy=wxy+Î·xyw_{xy} = w_{xy} + \eta xywxyâ=wxyâ+Î·xyï»¿

Logic: fire if combined input exceeds threshold

where d(x)d(x)d(x)ï»¿ = desired output in response, y(x)y(x)y(x)ï»¿ = actual output

MLP

â Simplest MLP is a step-function across a hyperplane

for x=[x1,â¦,xN]TâXâRNx = [x_1,\dots,x_N]^T \in X \subseteq \R^Nx=[x1â,â¦,xNâ]TâXâRNï»¿

Note: Single-layer MLP cannot compute XOR gate

A neural network can represent any function provided it has sufficient capacity (width & depth)

  • Universal classifiers
  • Composing complicated âdecisionâ boundaries

    â Increasing the number of sides reduces the area outside the polygon that have N2<âiyi<N\frac{N}{2} < \sum_i y_i <N2Nâ<âiâyiâ<Nï»¿

    âiyi=N(1â1Ïarccosâ¡(minâ¡(1,râ£xâxcâ£)))\sum_i y_i = N\left(1- \frac{1}{\pi} arc\cos \left(\min\left(1, \frac{r}{|x-x_c|}\right)\right)\right)âiâyiâ=N(1âÏ1âarccos(min(1,â£xâxcââ£râ)))ï»¿where xcx_cxcâï»¿ is center of circle

    â Compose any arbitrary figure with a number of circles (more accurate with greater number of smaller circles)

    â Compose arbitrary functions in any number of
    dimensions! â Even with only one hidden layer as sums of scaled and shifted cylinders

  • Deep structure â The input is the âsourceâ, the output nodes are âsinksâ, âdepthâ denotes longest path from source to sink
  • Single layer hidden network will require 2Nâ12^{N-1}2Nâ1ï»¿ perceptron in a hidden layer to represent NNNï»¿ Boolean variables
  • For a deep network, it will only requires 3(Nâ1)3(N-1)3(Nâ1)ï»¿ perceptrons â Linear in N!!!
    • An XOR needs 3 perceptrons (2 layers)
    • Can be arranged in only 2logâ¡2N 2\log_2 N2log2âNï»¿ layers
  • What if we have less than 2logâ¡2N2\log_2 N2log2âNï»¿ layers?
  • Narrow layers can still pass information to subsequent layers if the activation function is
    sufficiently graded
    • But will require greater depth, to permit later
      layers to capture pattern
  • The capacity of a network:
    • Information or Storage capacity: how many patterns can it remember
    • VC dimension
      • bounded by the square of the number of weights in the network
  • More analytical results
    • [Valient et al., ICML â14] A polynomial of degree n requires a network of depth (logâ¡n)2(\log n)^2(logn)2ï»¿
    • [Mhaskar et al., â16] all functions that can be expressed as a binary tree

Size of MLP << size of truth table

  • Largest irreducible DNF

    â requires 8 perceptrons

Optimal depth?

ââ(N+2)28â \left\lfloor \frac{(N+2)^2}{8}\right\rfloorâ8(N+2)2ââï»¿ neurons in 2nd hidden layer (quadratic, not exponential)

â because data âR2\in \R^2âR2ï»¿

â for general case of NNNï»¿ mutually intersecting hyperplanes in DDDï»¿ dims, we will need O(ND(Dâ1)!)\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{N^D}{(D-1)!}\right)O((Dâ1)!NDâ)ï»¿ weights (assume N>>DN>>DN>>Dï»¿)

â Other activations

Radial Basis Functions
  • radial symmetry, instead of linear symmetry
  • can compose cylinder-like outputs with just a single unit with appropriate choice of bandwidth Î²\betaÎ²ï»¿ (or activation
    function)
    • As opposed to units for the linear perceptron
How to train a NN (L3, Sep 4 - L8, Sep 20)

Learn a NN

Estimate parameter WWWï»¿ from sample data XdataX_{data}Xdataâï»¿

Problem: g(X)g(X)g(X)ï»¿ is unknown

â Sample di=g(Xi)+Ïµid_i = g(X_i) + \epsilon_idiâ=g(Xiâ)+Ïµiâï»¿

â The empirical error (risk)

  • Assume network architecture is sufficient for such a fit
  • Assume unique output dddï»¿ at any XXXï»¿
  • Hopefully the resulting function is also correct where we donât have
    training samples

Task: binary classification (correct: error = 0; wrong: error = 1)

Learning the classifier: Minimizing the count of misclassifications

  • Individual neurons represent one of the lines that compose the figure (linear classifiers)
    • Must know the desired output of every neuron for every training instance, in
      order to learn this neuron.
    • The linear separators must combine to
      form the desired boundary

â At least exponential (in inputs) time complexity!!!

y={1Â ifÂ âi=1NwiXi+bâ¥00Â o.w.y = \begin{cases}1 & \text{ if } \sum_{i=1}^N w_i X_i+b \geq 0\\ 0 & \text{ o.w.} \end{cases}y={10âÂ ifÂ âi=1NâwiâXiâ+bâ¥0Â o.w.âï»¿

  • Boundary âi=1NwiXi+b=0\sum_{i=1}^N w_i X_i+b = 0âi=1NâwiâXiâ+b=0ï»¿
  • Want to learn W=[w1â¦wN]TW = [w_1 \dots w_N]^T W=[w1ââ¦wNâ]Tï»¿, and bbbï»¿ given (X,y)(X,y)(X,y)ï»¿ pairs

Convergence

  • Guaranteed to converge after (RÎ³)2\left(\frac{R}{\gamma}\right)^2(Î³Râ)2ï»¿ misclassifications (i.e. iterations) if classes are linearly separable where
    • RR Rï»¿ is length of longest training point
    • Î³\gammaÎ³ï»¿ is the best case closest distance of a training point from the classifier
  • When classes are not linearly separable, it is not possible to find a separating hyperplane
    • No âsupportâ plane for reflected data
    • Some points will always lie on the other side

    â Perceptron algorithm will never converge!!!

    • MADALINE (Multiple ADALINE)

    â Effective for small networks

    â Too expensive for large nets

â small change in weight can result in non-negligible changes in output with the perceptron â no indication of which direction to update the weights

â individual neuronsâ weights can change significantly without changing overall error

  • Gradient Descent

    Closed form solution of âxf(X)=0\nabla_{\mathbf{x}} f(X) = 0âxâf(X)=0ï»¿ is not always available â iterative solution

    Problems:

    • Which direction to step in
    • How big must the steps be
    • Start from initial guess X0X_0X0âï»¿
    • Update the guess towards a (hopefully) âbetterâ value of f(X)f(X)f(X)ï»¿
    • Stop when f(X)f(X)f(X)ï»¿ no longer decreases

    Convergence of GD

    • For appropriate step size, for convex functions GD will always find the minimum.
    • For non-convex functions, it will find a local minimum or an inflection point

Convergence

â Is backpropagation always right?

â How well does it learn? How well will it generalize outside training data?

  • [Brady, Raghavan, Slawny, â89] Backprop fails to separate where perceptron succeeds!

Unique solution exists for this simple setup

  • wx.1+wy.0+b=uw_x.1+w_y.0+ b =uwxâ.1+wyâ.0+b=uï»¿
  • wx.0+wy.1+b=uw_x.0+w_y.1+ b =uwxâ.0+wyâ.1+b=uï»¿
  • wx.(â1)+wy.0+b=âuw_x.(-1)+w_y.0+ b =-uwxâ.(â1)+wyâ.0+b=âuï»¿

âââï»¿ wx=u,wy=u,b=0w_x = u, w_y=u, b=0wxâ=u,wyâ=u,b=0ï»¿ for some uuuï»¿.

â both backprop and perceptron
algorithms find solutions

  • Perceptron may change greatly upon adding just a single new training instance
    • Makes no errors if possibleâ But high variance
    • Can swings wildly in response to small changes to input
  • Backprop is minimally changed by new training instances
    • Prefers consistency over perfection
    • Low-variance estimator, at the potential cost of bias
  • t>>0t>>0 t>>0ï»¿ - perceptron may take t2t^2t2ï»¿ iteration to find the solution
  • For t>>0t>>0t>>0ï»¿, â£wyâ£>Ïµ|w_y|>\epsilonâ£wyââ£>Ïµï»¿
    • (1âÏµâÏ(âwy+b))â1(1-\epsilon-\sigma(-w_y+b))â 1(1âÏµâÏ(âwyâ+b))â1ï»¿ as tââtâ \inftytââï»¿

    âdDiv4dwy=dDiv4db=0â \frac{d Div_4}{dw_y} = \frac{d Div_4}{db} =0âdwyâdDiv4ââ=dbdDiv4ââ=0ï»¿

â (0,ât)(0,-t)(0,ât)ï»¿ does not change the gradient of the L2 divergence near the optimal solution for 3 points
â The optimum solution for 3 points is also a broad local minimum (0 gradient) for the 4-point problem!

  • The loss surface
    • Saddle points (slope=0, some of the eigenvalues of Hessian are positive, some are negative) are far more common than local minima
      • Frequency of occurrence exponential in network size
      • Most local minima are equivalent & close to global minimum
      • This is not true for small networks
      • Gradient descent algorithms often get âstuckâ in saddle points
    • Neural network loss surface is generally not convex (Streetlight effect)
      • KL loss is convex as a function of weights for a single-layer perceptron (for 2-dimensional inputs {(xi,yi)}iâ[n]\{(x_i,y_i)\}_{i\in[n]}{(xiâ,yiâ)}iâ[n]âï»¿), while L2 is not.

  • Simultaneously adjust the function at all training points
    • Process all training points before making a single
      adjustment
    • âBatchâ update
  • Incremental update (stochastic GD)
    • Why incremental update works?
      • Individual training instances contribute different directions to the overall gradient (final gradient points is the average of individual gradients)
      • Consider case where X1=X2=â¯=XDX_1=X_2 = \dots=X_DX1â=X2â=â¯=XDâï»¿ (data clotting)
    • As data get increasingly diverse, the benefits of incremental updates decrease, but do not entirely vanish.
    • When does incremental update works?

      â The model to always minimize the error on the latest instance, hence limit the convergence

      â Shrink the learning rate with iterations â parameters swing less and less towards the new point

    • SGD converges âalmost surelyâ to a global or local minimum for most functions.
      • Sufficient condition: step sizes follow the following conditions
        [Robbins and Munro, 1951]
        âkÎ·k=â\sum_k \eta_k=ââkâÎ·kâ=âï»¿
        • Eventually the entire parameter space can be searched âkÎ·k2<â\sum_k \eta_k^2 <\inftyâkâÎ·k2â<âï»¿
        • The steps shrink!
      • The fastest converging series that satisfies both above requirements Î·kâ1k\eta_k\propto\frac{1}{k}Î·kââk1âï»¿ (the optimal rate of shrinking the step size for strongly convex functions, or heuristically determined)
      • If the loss is convex, SGD converges to the optimal solution; otherwise, it converges to a local minimum
  • The empirical risk is an unbiased estimate of the expected divergence:

    Loss(W)=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]âE[Loss(W)]=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]Loss(W) = \mathbb{E} [div(f(X;W),g(X))] â \mathbb{E} [Loss(W)] = \mathbb{E} [div(f(X;W),g(X))] Loss(W)=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]âE[Loss(W)]=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]ï»¿

    • Having very few samples makes the estimate swing wildly with the sample position
    • But SGD provides significantly quicker updates than batch âââï»¿ Mini-batch
  • Mini-batch update
    • Adjust the function at a small, randomly chosen subset of points.
    • Vary the subsets randomly in different passes through the training data

    Larger minibatches

    = less variance
    = few updates per epoch

    Mini-batch loss:

    MBLoss(W)=1bâi=1bdiv(f(Xi;W),g(Xi))MBLoss(W) = \frac{1}{b} \sum_{i=1}^b div(f(X_i;W),g(X_i)) MBLoss(W)=b1ââi=1bâdiv(f(Xiâ;W),g(Xiâ))ï»¿

    âE[MBLoss(W)]=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]â \mathbb{E} [MBLoss(W)] = \mathbb{E} [div(f(X;W),g(X))] âE[MBLoss(W)]=E[div(f(X;W),g(X))]ï»¿

    var[MBLoss]=1bvar[div] var[MBLoss] = \frac{1}{b}var[div]var[MBLoss]=b1âvar[div]ï»¿ where b<<Nb << Nb<<Nï»¿

Generalization

  • Batch Normalization (BN)

    â Training assumes the training data are all similarly distributed, but this is not always the case in practice!!

    • Each minibatch may have a different distribution â âcovariate shiftâ
      • The shifts can be large!
      • Can affect training badly!

      â âMoveâ all batches to a âstandardâ (mean 000ï»¿ and unit standard variance) location of the space and shift to appropriate spot.

    • Trainingâ¦
      • Because of BN (divided by mean of all sample), the training instances within the mini-batch are no longer independent
      • Derivative of the loss w.r.t Î³\gammaÎ³ï»¿ and Î²\betaÎ²ï»¿ can be easily calculated, and so for every uiu_iuiâï»¿.
      • For every i=ji=ji=jï»¿ pair
      • For iâ ji\neq jiî =jï»¿

    To compute the derivative of minibatch loss w.r.t any ziz_iziâï»¿, we must consider all z^j\hat{z}_jz^jâï»¿ in the batch

    • Inference
      • BN requires Î¼B\mu_BÎ¼Bâï»¿, ÏB2\sigma_B^2ÏB2âï»¿ for test data â achieve this by averaging all training minibatches
        • Î¼B=1NbatchesâbatchÎ¼B(batch)\mu_B = \frac{1}{N_{\text{batches}}} \sum_{\text{batch}} \mu_B (\text{batch})Î¼Bâ=Nbatchesâ1ââbatchâÎ¼Bâ(batch)ï»¿
        • ÏB2=B(Bâ1)NbatchesâbatchÏB2(batch)\sigma^2_B = \frac{B}{(B-1)N_{\text{batches}}} \sum_{\text{batch}} \sigma^2_B (\text{batch})ÏB2â=(Bâ1)NbatchesâBââbatchâÏB2â(batch)ï»¿ (unbiased estimator for the variance)

        where Î¼B(batch) \mu_B (\text{batch})Î¼Bâ(batch)ï»¿ and ÏB2(batch)\sigma^2_B (\text{batch})ÏB2â(batch)ï»¿ are obtained from the final converged network.

      • BN may only be applied to some layers (or even only selected neurons in the layer)
      • Improves both convergence rate and neural network performance
        • Anecdotal evidence that BN eliminates the need for dropout
        • To get maximum benefit from BN, learning rates must be increased and learning rate decay can be faster since the data generally remain in the high-gradient regions of the activations
        • Also needs better randomization of training data order.
  • Smoothing
    • Consider a binary 100-dimensional input
    • There are 2100=10302^{100} = 10^{30}2100=1030ï»¿ possible inputs
    • Complete specification of the function will require specification of 103010^{30}1030ï»¿ output values.
    • A training set with only 101510^{15}1015ï»¿ training instances will be off by a factor of 101510^{15}1015ï»¿

    â Steep changes that enable overfitted responses are facilitated by perceptrons with large wwwï»¿.

    â Constraining the weights to be low will force slower perceptrons and smoother output response â Regularization.

    • The âdesiredâ output is generally smooth - capture statistical or average trends.
    • Unconstrained model will model individual instances instead.

    Smoothness through network structure

    • For a given number of parameters deeper networks impose more smoothness than shallow ones
    • Training with more data is also better :))

    Other smoothing techniques:

    • L1L_1L1âï»¿ regularization of network activations
    • Regularizing with added noise
    • Bagging (proposed by Leo Breiman)
      • Sample training data and train several different classifiers
      • Classify test instance with entire ensemble of classifiers
      • Vote across classifiers for final decision
      • Empirically shown to improve significantly over training a single classifier from combined data

  • Dropout

    â Training: For each input, at each iteration, âturn offâ each neuron (including inputs) with a probability 1âÎ±1-\alpha1âÎ±ï»¿

    • In practice, set them to 0 according to the failure of a Bernoulli random number generator with success probability Î±\alphaÎ±ï»¿
    • Backpropagation is effectively performed only over the remaining
      network
      • The effective network is different for different inputs
      • Gradients are obtained only for the weights and biases from âOnâ nodes to âOnâ nodes (for the remaining, the gradient is just 0)
    • Forward pass
    • Backward pass

    â Testing

    • For a network with a total of NNNï»¿ neurons, there are 2N2^N2Nï»¿ possible sub-networks
      • Obtained by choosing different subsets of nodes
      • Dropout samples over all 2N2^N2Nï»¿ possible networks
      • Effectively learns a network that averages over all possible networks (Bagging)
    • Dropout forces the neurons to
      learn ârichâ and redundant patterns
      • E.g. without dropout, a non
        compressive layer may just âcloneâ its input to its output
        • Transferring the task of learning to the rest of the network upstream
    • Dropout forces the neurons to
      learn denser patterns

    What each neuron computes?

    where DDDï»¿ is a Bernoulli variable that takes a value 111ï»¿ with probability Î±\alphaÎ±ï»¿.

    • On test data, the output is the ensemble average over 2N2^N2Nï»¿ networks (statistical expectation of the output over all networks)

    is expected output of the iiiï»¿th neuron in the kkkï»¿th layer over all networks.

    i.e. scaling each output of each neuron by Î±\alphaÎ±ï»¿

    • Alternatively, replace the activation by Î±â1Ï(.)\alpha^{-1} \sigma(.) Î±â1Ï(.)ï»¿
      • Can later use regular activation Ï(.)\sigma(.)Ï(.)ï»¿ during testing without needs to modify the weights

    Variations

    • Zoneout (for RNNs): randomly chosen units remain unchanged across a time transition
    • Dropconnect: drop individual connections, instead of nodes
    • Shakeout: scale up the weights of randomly selected weights & fix remaining weights to a negative constant
    • Whiteout: add or multiply weight-dependent Gaussian noise to the signal on
      each connection
  • Some other tricks (heuristics)
    • Early stopping
      • Continued training can result in over fitting to training data
      • Track performance on a held-out validation set
      • Apply one of several early-stopping criterion to terminate training when performance on validation set degrades significantly

    • Gradient clipping

      â Instability training when the DivDivDivï»¿ has a steep slope

      • Set a ceiling on derivative value: if âwDiv>Î±\nabla_{\mathcal{w}}Div > \alphaâwâDiv>Î±ï»¿, then âwDivâÎ±\nabla_{\mathcal{w}}Div â \alphaâwâDivâÎ±ï»¿.
    • Data augmentation

      â Available training data will often be small

      • âExtendâ it by distorting examples in a variety of ways to generate synthetic labelled examples
      • E.g. rotation, stretching, adding noise, etc.
    • Input normalization

    • 1st layer evaluates smaller blocks of pixels
    • The next layer evaluates the windows of outputs from the first layer
    • Distribution forces hierarchical representations with localized patterns in lower layers
      • More generalizable
    • Fewer computations
      • Reusable computations from lower layers
    • Far fewer number of parameter

General architecture of a convolutional neural network (CNN)

  • Study on neural correlates of vision [Hubel and Wiesel, 1959]
  • Show complex buildup â building more complex patterns by composing early neural responses
    • Successive transformation through Simple-Complex combination layers
  • Complex C-cells build from similarly oriented simple cells
    • They âfine-tuneâ the response of the simple cell
  • NeoCognitron [Kunihiko Fukushima, 1980]
    • Positional invariance of input: âYour grandmother cell fires even if your grandmother
      moves to a different location in your field of vision.â
    • Visual system consists of a hierarchy of modules, each comprising a layer of âS-cellsâ followed by a layer of âC-cellsâ
      • S-cells respond to the signal in the previous layer (learnable)
      • C-cells confirm the S-cellsâ response (fixed)
    • U0U_0U0âï»¿ is the retina
    • The deeper the layer, the larger the receptive field of each neuron
      • Cell planes get smaller with layer number
      • Number of planes increases
    • Unsupervised learning:
      • Randomly initialize S cells, perform Hebbian learning updates in response to input
        • Îwij=ð¥iyj\Delta w_{ij} =ð¥_i y_jÎwijâ=xiâyjâï»¿
        • Within any layer, at any position, only the maximum SSSï»¿ from all the layers is
          selected for update
          • Also viewed as max-valued cell from each S column
            • Ensures only one of the planes picks up any feature
            • If multiple max selections are on the same plane, only the largest is chosen
          • But across all positions, multiple planes will be selected
          • Updates are distributed across all cells within the plane
      • Ensures different planes learn different features
        • E.g. Given many examples of the character âAâ the different cell planes in the S-C layers may learn the patterns shown
        • Given other characters, other planes will learn their components
        • Going up the layers goes from local to global receptor fields
          • Winner-take-all strategy makes it robust to distortion
          • Unsupervised: Effectively clustering
      • The neocognitron is fully unsupervised
        • Semantic labels are automatically learned
          • Can we add external supervision?
            • Temporal correlation: Homma, Atlas, Marks, â88
            • TDNN: Lang, Waibel et. al., 1989, â90
            • Convolutional neural networks: LeCun
      • Add an extra decision layer after the final C layer - produces a class-label output

        = a fully feed forward MLP with shared parameters

        • All the S-cells within an S-plane have the same weights
        • Train the S-cell weights in every plane of every layer with backpropagation
        • C-cells are not updated

      Note: The original Neocognitron actually uses many identical copies of a neuron in each S and C plane = âscanningâ with a single copy

      • Assuming square receptive fields, rather than elliptical ones
      • Receptive field of S cells in lllï»¿th layer is KlÃKlK_l \times K_lKlâÃKlâï»¿
      • Receptive field of C cells in lllï»¿th layer is LlÃLlL_l \times L_lLlâÃLlâï»¿
        • C cells âstrideâ by more than one pixel, resulting in a shrinking, or âdown-samplingâ of the maps

  • A convolutional layer

What is a convolution?

â Scanning an image with a âfilterâ

â The âcubeâ view of input maps

The computation of the convolutional map at any location sums the convolutional outputs at all planes.

  • Convolutional layers and the MLP are learnable
    • Corresponding the âS-planesâ in the Neocognitron
    • Each convolutional layer is an affine map with an activation.
  • Pooling layers are fixed and generally not learnable

  • Engineering consideration
    • Zero-padding
      • Note that image size = NÃNN\times NNÃNï»¿, filter size = MÃMM\times MMÃMï»¿

        â output size = (NâM)+1Ã(NâM)+1(N-M) +1 \times (N-M) + 1(NâM)+1Ã(NâM)+1ï»¿ â sometimes is not acceptable!

      • Zero-pad the input so that convolution has the same size as the original image
        • Odd LLLï»¿-width filter: Pad on both left and right with Lâ12\frac{L-1}{2}2Lâ1âï»¿ columns of zeros
        • Even LLLï»¿-width filter: Pad one side with L2\frac{L}{2}2Lâï»¿ columns of zeros, and the other with L2â1\frac{L}{2} -12Lââ1ï»¿ columns of zeros
        • The resulting image is width N+Lâ1N+L -1N+Lâ1ï»¿
        • The result of the convolution is width NNNï»¿
    • Pooling

      â âscanningâ the input

      • Max pooling
      • Mean pooling
      • p-norm
      • A learned NN filter
    • Downsampling

      â An NÃNN\times NNÃNï»¿ input compressed by a PÃPP\times PPÃPï»¿ pooling filter with stride DDDï»¿ results in an output map of size âNâPDâ+1ÃâNâPDâ+1\left\lceil \frac{N-P}{D} \right\rceil + 1 \times \left\lceil \frac{N-P}{D} \right\rceil + 1 âDNâPââ+1ÃâDNâPââ+1ï»¿

      â Shrinking of the map

    • Upsampling
      • Introduces rows and columns for every map in the layer
        • Effectively increasing the size of the map by factor in every direction
      • Used explicitly to increase the map size by a uniform factor
      • Not useful to follow it by a pooling layer nor as the final layer of a CNN

      â Upsampling by factor SSSï»¿ is the same as striding by factor 1S\frac{1}{S}S1âï»¿

  • End-to-end Convolutional Neural Networks
    • Preprocessing
      • 3 RGB channels
      • Scaled to smaller sizes, e.g. 128Ã128128\times 128128Ã128ï»¿ or even 32Ã3232 \times 3232Ã32ï»¿ - based on how much will fit on GPU
      • Typically cropped to square image
    • Input is convolved with a set of K1K_1K1âï»¿ filters
      • Typically K1K_1K1âï»¿ is a power of 222ï»¿, e.g. 2,4,8,16,32,â¦2, 4, 8, 16, 32,â¦2,4,8,16,32,â¦ï»¿
      • Better notation: Filters are typically 5Ã5(Ã3)5\times5(\times3)5Ã5(Ã3)ï»¿, 3Ã3(Ã3)3\times3(\times3)3Ã3(Ã3)ï»¿, or even 1Ã1(Ã3)1\times1(\times3)1Ã1(Ã3)ï»¿
      • Typical stride: 111ï»¿ or 222ï»¿
      • Zero-padded according to the size of the chosen filter
      • Followed by a ReLU activation
      • Downsampling
    • Parameters to be learned:
      • The weights of the neurons in the final MLP
      • The (weights and biases of the) filters for every convolutional layer
    • E.g. Digit classification
  • Learning the CNN
    • Total parameters required for the convolutional layers:
    • Training CNN through GD
    • Backpropagation

        where fffï»¿ is the activation function.

        • Each Y(lâ1,m)Y(l-1,m)Y(lâ1,m)ï»¿ map/channel influences Z(l,n)Z(l,n)Z(l,n)ï»¿ through the mmmï»¿th âplaneâ (channel) of the nnnï»¿th filter wl(m,n)w_l(m,n)wlâ(m,n)ï»¿

          • z(l,n,xâ,yâ)z(l,n,xâ,yâ) z(l,n,xâ,yâ)ï»¿ += Y(lâ1,m,x,y)wl(m,n,xâxâ,yâyâ)Y(l-1,m,x,y)w_l(m,n,x-xâ,y-yâ)Y(lâ1,m,x,y)wlâ(m,n,xâxâ,yâyâ)ï»¿

          â also is a convolution

      • For pooling layers, compute the derivative w.r.t Y(lâ1)Y(l-1)Y(lâ1)ï»¿ given derivatives w.r.t. Y(l)Y(l)Y(l)ï»¿
        • Max pooling layer

          For kâ{i,i+Klpoolâ1},nâ{j,j+Klpoolâ1}k\in\{i,i+K_{lpool} -1\}, n\in\{j,j+K_{lpool}-1\}kâ{i,i+Klpoolââ1},nâ{j,j+Klpoolââ1}ï»¿,

          = channel-wise convolution of dy(l,m)dy(l,m)dy(l,m)ï»¿ by a âuniformâ filter with value 1Klpool2\frac{1}{K_{lpool}^2}Klpool2â1âï»¿

      • Backprop through down-sampling layer
        1. Allocate a map of the size of the input that was down-sampled
        1. The âdeletedâ values (blackened) do not affect the output (derivative w.r.t. these elements is 000ï»¿)
        1. The remaining values are identical in the original and down-sampled maps in the forward pass - the divergence derivatives too will be identical
        # H and W are the height and width of the input
# to the downsampling layer in the forward pass
# S is the stride in the forward pass
# dz contains the divergence derivative for the D/S
# output z in the forward pass

function dy = backprop_through_DS(dz, S, H, W)
	#c = number of channels in dz
	dy = zeros(c,H,W)  # preallocate to right size and set to 0
	for i = 1:width(z)
		for j = 1:height(z)
			dy(:,(i-1)S+1, (j-1)S+1) = dz(:,i,j)
	return dy
      • Backprop through the up-sampling layer
        # S is the stride in the forward pass
# dz contains the divergence derivative for the U/S
# output z in the forward pass

function dy = backprop_through_Upsampling (dz, S)
	#c = number of channels in dz
	k = 0
	for i = 1:S:width(z)
		l = 0
		for j = 1:S:height(z)
			dy(:,k, l) = dz(:,i,j)
			l++
		k++
	return dy

Invariance

â Generalize shift-invariance = transform invariance

  • Shift-invariance
  • Transform invariance (TtT_t Ttâï»¿= rotation, scaling, reflections etc.)

â Derivatives flow back through the transforms to update individual filters â Need point
correspondences between original and transformed filters.

Common tasks
  • Finding bounding boxes

    The flatten layer outputs to two separate output layers

    • One predicts the class of the output
    • The second predicts the corners of the bounding box of the object (8 coordinates)

    The divergence minimized is the sum of the cross-entropy loss of the classifier layer and L2 loss of the bounding-box predictor

    â Multi-task learning

  • Pose estimation
    • Use the same mechanism to predict the joints of a stick model

Well-known architectures

  • Conventional convolutions
    • Each layer of each filter scans its corresponding map to produce a convolved map
    • N input channels will require a filter with N layers
    • The independent convolutions of each layer of the filter result in N convolved maps
    • The N convolved maps are added together to produce the final output map (or channel) for that filter
  • Depth-wise convolution
    • The convolution step is performed only once
    • The simple summation is replaced by a weighted sum across channels - different weights (for summation) produce different output channels
  • Le-net 5

    Digit recognition on MNIST (32Ã3232\times3232Ã32ï»¿ images)

  • Training issues
    • Standard convergence issues â Adam or other momentum-style algorithms + batch normalization

      • Rotation: uniformly chosen random angle between 0Â° and 360Â°
      • Translation: random translation between -10 and 10 pixels
      • Rescaling: random scaling with scale factor between 1/1.6 and 1.6 (log-uniform)
      • Flipping: yes or no (Bernoulli)
      • Shearing: random shearing with angle between -20Â° and 20Â°
      • Stretching: random stretching with stretch factor between 1/1.3 and 1.3 (log-uniform)

    â Receptive fields

    â For the higher level neurons, the actual receptive field is not immediately obvious
    and must be calculated

    • What patterns in the input do the neurons actually respond to?
    • Estimate the receptive field by setting the output of the neuron to 1, and learning the input by backpropagation

RNN (L13, Oct 9 - L17, Oct 30)

Sequence of vectors â classification result (eg: past stock data â buy or sell)

Eg: Text analysis (identify topic, translation - English to French)

Finite-response model

NNNï»¿ is width of the system (prediction consider N points of history)

( also called a Time-Delay neural network)

Problem: Increasing âhistoryâ makes the network more complex (& lack of computer memory) but real system usually have long-term dependencies

â want infinite response systems

NARX network

= âNonlinear Autoregressive network with exogenous inputsâ

âMemoryâ of the past is in the output YtY_tYtâï»¿ and not in the network.

â want to ârememberâ the past

Simple recurrent networks:

Jordan networks maintain a running average of outputs in a âmemoryâ unit

  • Consider entire past, rather than immediate past

Elman networks store hidden unit values for one time instant in a âcontextâ unit that carry historical state

  • Only the weight from the memory unit to the hidden unit is learned
  • During training no gradient is backpropagated over the â1â link

State-space models

hth_thtâï»¿ is the state of the network (summarizes information about the entire past)

â need to define hâ1h_{-1}hâ1âï»¿

Training a RNN

Â *Â f1\text{ * } f_1Â *Â f1âï»¿ is usually the tanhâ¡\tanh tanhï»¿ function.

Backpropagation through time

  • Forward pass: pass the entire data sequence through the network, generate outputs
    # Assuming h(-1,*) is known
# Assuming L hidden-state layers and an output layer
# W_c(*) and W_r(*) are matrics, b(*) are vectors
# W_c are weights for inputs from current time
# W_r is recurrent weight applied to the previous time
# W_o are output layre weights

for t in range(T): # Including both ends of the index
	h(t,0) = x(t) # Vectors. Initialize h(0) to input
	for l in range(L+1): # hidden layers operate at time t
		z(t,l) = W_c(l)*h(t,l-1) + W_r(l)*h(t-1,l) + b(l)
		h(t,l) = tanh(z(t,l)) # Assuming tanh activation function
	z_o(t) = W_o*h(t,L) + b_o
Y(t) = softmax( z_o (t) )
  • Backward pass: compute gradients via backpropagation

    â Compute âY(T)DIV(Y(0:T),X(0:T))\nabla_{Y(T)}DIV(Y(0:T),X(0:T)) âY(T)âDIV(Y(0:T),X(0:T))ï»¿, where Div(t)Div(t)Div(t)ï»¿ measure the divergence of desire output & the output by the network (usually cross-entropy loss or MSE).

    • Suppose DIV=âtDiv(t)DIV = \sum_t Div(t)DIV=âtâDiv(t)ï»¿

    Some calculus rules

    • Z(2)(t)Z^{(2)}(t)Z(2)(t)ï»¿ is the pre-activation value of the neurons at the output layer at time t
    • Z(1)(t)Z^{(1)}(t)Z(1)(t)ï»¿ is the pre-activation value of the hidden layer at time
    • Y(t)Y( t)Y(t)ï»¿ is the output at time
    • h(t)h(t)h(t)ï»¿ is the output of the hidden layer at time

    Gradient derivation

    # Assuming forward pass has been completed
# Jacobian(x,y) is the jacobian of x w.r.t. y
# Assuming dY(t) = gradient(div,Y(t)) available for all t
# Assuming all dz, dh, dW and db are initialized to 0

for t in range(T,0): # Backward through time
	dz_o(t) = dY(t)*Jacobian(Y(t),z_o(t))
	dW_o += h(t,L)dz_o(t)
	db_o += dz_o(t)
	dh(t,L) += dz_o(t)W_o
	for l in range(L+1,0): # Reverse through layers
		dz(t,l) = dh(t,l)Jacobian(h(t,l),z(t,l))
		dh(t,l-1) += dz(t,l)*Wc(l)
		dh(t-1,l) = dz(t,l)*Wr(l)
		dW_c(l) += h(t,l-1)*dz(t,l)
		dW_r(l) += h(t-1,l)*dz(t,l)
		db(l) += dz(t,l)

â Can be generalize to any RNN architecture

Some architectures

  • One-to-one (conventional MLP)
  • One-to-many (sequence generation, image captioning)

    Decoding

    • Given image â process it with CNN to get output of classification layer
    • Sequentially generate words by drawing from the conditional output distribution.

    Training: given several (Image, Caption) pairs â The image network is pretrained on a large corpus, e.g. ImageNet

    • Forward pass: Produce output distributions given the image and caption
    • Backward pass: Compute the divergence w.r.t. training caption, and backpropagate derivatives
      • All components of the network, including final classification layer of the image classification net are updated
      • The CNN portions of the image classifier are not modified (transfer learning)

    # Assuming encoded input H (from text, image, video)  is available
# Now generate the output y_out(1),y_out(2),â¦
t = 0
h_out(0) = H   # Encoder embedding

# Note: begins with a âstart of sentenceâ symbol <sos>
y_out(0) = <sos>
do
	t = t+1
	[y(t),h_out(t)] = RNN_output_step(h_out(t-1), y_out(t-1), H)
	y_out(t) = generate(y(t)) # Beam search, random, or greedy
until y_out(t) == <eos>

  • Many-to-one (speech recognition, question & answer)
    • Output generated when last vector processed (probability distribution over phonemes)
    • Output are actually produced for every input, but we only read at the end
    • Divergence only defined at the final input (propagate through the net to update all parameters)
    • But the net can assume the previous block is not useful
      • Trick: assign last output to every input to have one-to-one correspondence
      • Compute the weighted sum of divergence instead (e.g. set all weights except last one to 0 or some small value)
  • Many-to-many (input â \neqî =ï»¿ output â machine translation, input = output â stock prediction)
    • Time-synchronous network (e.g. Part-of-Speech tagging)
      • 1 input â 1 output
    • Order synchronous, time asynchronous sequence-to-sequence generation
      • E.g. speech recognition â Exact location of output is unknown a prior
      • Solve by compare outputs to the next one and output if different

        â Cannot distinguish between an extended symbol and repetitions of the symbol

      • Impose external constraints on what sequences are allowed
        • Only allow sequences corresponding to dictionary words
        • Using special âseparatingâ symbols to separate repetitio

        â do not guarantee optimal order-synchronous sequences

        n = 1
best(1)= argmax_i(y(1,i))
for t = 1:T
	best(t)= argmax_i(y(t,i))
	if (best(t) != best(t-1))
		 out(n) = best(t-1)
		 time(n) = t-1
		 n = n+1
      • How to train?
        • Output sequence length <= input sequence length
        • The time-stamps of the output symbols give us the âalignmentâ of the
          output sequence to the input sequence - but we donât know that given the output sequence
        • Training without alignment
          • Given unaligned KKKï»¿-length compressed symbol sequence S=S0â¦SKâ1S = S_0 \dots S_{K-1}S=S0ââ¦SKâ1âï»¿, an NNNï»¿-length input (Nâ¥KNâ¥ KNâ¥Kï»¿) X=X0â¦XNâ1X = X_0 \dots X_{N-1}X=X0ââ¦XNâ1âï»¿ and a trained RNN
          • Find the best expansion of a compressed sequence, for a given input, given a model (Connectionist Temporal Classification)
          • Guess the alignment
            • Iteratively refine an initial alignment as the model improves
              • Initialize: Assign an initial alignment â Either randomly, based on some heuristic, or any other rationale
              • Iterate: Train the network using the current alignment â Re-estimate the alignment for each training instance
          • Select the most likely alignments
            • Copy output values for the target symbols into the secondary reduced structure (remove all values that not belongs to the set of target symbols - get rid of unnecessary outputs)
            • Arrange the constructed table so that from top to bottom it has the exact sequence of symbols required
            • Compose a graph such that every path in the graph from source to
              sink represents a valid alignment â maps on to the target symbol sequence (e.g. /B//IY//F//IY/)
              • Edge scores are 1
              • Node scores are the probabilities assigned to the symbols by the neural network

              â Find the most probable path (e.g. via Viterbi algorithm)

            • Constrain that the first symbol in the decode must be the top left block
              • The last symbol must be the bottom right
              • The rest must follow a sequence that monotonically travels
                down from top left to bottom right â i.e. symbol chosen at any time is at the same level or at the next level to the symbol at the previous time
              • This guarantees that the sequence is an expansion of the target sequence

            • Viterbi algorithm
              • Best path to any node must be an extension of the best path to one of its parent nodes
              • Notations:
                • ytS(r)y_t^{S(r)}ytS(r)âï»¿ is the probability of the target symbols assigned to the rrrï»¿th row at the tttï»¿-th time (given input X0,â¦,XTX_0, \dots, X_TX0â,â¦,XTâï»¿)
               #N is the number of symbols in the target output
 #S(i) is the ith symbol in target output
 #T = length of input
 
 #First create output table
 For i = 1:N
	 s(1:T,i) = y(1:T, S(i))
 
 #Now run the Viterbi algorithm
 # First, at t = 1
 BP(1,1) = -1               # assign y(1,S(1)) to be 1st best parent
 Bscr(1,1) = s(1,1)         # initialize 1st best path score to node
 Bscr(1,2:N) = 0
 for t = 2:T
	 BP(t,1) = 1;
	 Bscr(t,1) = Bscr(t-1,1)*s(t,1)
	 for i = 1:min(t,N)
		  if Bscr(t-1,i) > Bscr(t-1,i-1)
				 BP(t,i) = i
		  else
				 BP(t,i) = i-1
		 Bscr(t,i) = Bscr(t-1,BP(t,i))*s(t,i)
	
 # Backtrace
 AlignedSymbol(T) = N
 for t = T downto 2
	 AlignedSymbol(t-1) = BP(t,AlignedSymbol(t))

            • Gradient from the alignment

              Gradient w.r.t the output vector YtY_tYtâï»¿ (Zeros except at the component corresponding to the target in the estimated alignment)

          • Instead of only selecting the most likely alignment, use the statistical expectation over all possible alignments
            • Use the entire distribution of alignments â mitigate the issue of suboptimal selection of alignment
            • Need to able to compute P(st=Srâ£S,X)âP(st=Sr,Sâ£X)P(s_t = S_r|\mathbf{S},\mathbf{X}) \propto P(s_t = S_r,\mathbf{S}|\mathbf{X})P(stâ=Srââ£S,X)âP(stâ=Srâ,Sâ£X)ï»¿

            where

            • Î±(t,r)=âq:Sqâpred(Sr)Î±(tâ1,q)ytSr\alpha(t,r) = \sum_{q:S_q \in pred(S_r)} \alpha(t-1, q) y_t^{S_r}Î±(t,r)=âq:Sqââpred(Srâ)âÎ±(tâ1,q)ytSrââï»¿ is the total probability of the red subgraph

              â in practice, compute logâ¡Î±(t,l)=logâ¡(Î±(tâ1,l)+Î±(tâ1,lâ1))+logâ¡ytS(l)\log \alpha(t,l) = \log (\alpha(t-1,l) + \alpha(t-1, l-1)) + \log y_t^S(l)logÎ±(t,l)=log(Î±(tâ1,l)+Î±(tâ1,lâ1))+logytSâ(l)ï»¿ to prevent underflow.

              #N is the number of symbols in the target output

            âDiv=âârârÎ³(t,r)logâ¡ytS(r)â Div = - \sum_r\sum_r \gamma(t,r) \log y_t^{S(r)}âDiv=âârâârâÎ³(t,r)logytS(r)âï»¿

            • Backpropagate and aggregate derivatives over minibatch and update parameters
      • Decoding problem

        Consider a decode: R RRE EEED â Is this the compressed symbol sequence RED or REED.

        • Solution: add a â-â to separate symbols
          • The next symbol at the end of a sequence of blanks is always a new character
          • When a symbol repeats, there must be at least one blank between the repetitions
          • E.g. RRR---EE---DDD = RED, RR-E--EED = REED
          • The first and last column are allowed to also end at initial and
            final blanks
            • Skips are permitted across a blank, but only if the symbols on
              either side are different
            • Because a blank is mandatory between repetitions of a symbol but not required between distinct symbols
          • Include the blank â-â in the list of vocabulary during training
        • Greedy decodes are suboptimal - select most likely time synchronous
          symbol sequence
          • blank â-â capture the steady state in the speech, and other symbol peak up during transitioning

          â allow greedy decode to perform well

        • Actual decoding objective - find the most likely (asynchronous) symbol sequence
          • The semi-tree hypothesis
            • The semi tree of hypotheses (assuming only 3 symbols in the vocabulary)
            • Every symbol connects to every symbol other than itself â also connects to a blank, which connects to every symbol including itself
              • The simple structure repeats recursively
              • Each node represents a unique (partial) symbol sequence!

          The âtheoretically correctâ CTC decoder
          â In practice, the graph gets exponentially large very quickly
          â To prevent this, pruning strategies (top-K or top-p pruning) are employed to keep the graph (and computation) manageable

          â This may cause suboptimal decodes, however â The fact that CTC scores peak at symbol terminations minimizes the damage due to pruning

          • Beam search
    • No correspondence between input & output - order asynchronous (delayed sequence-to-sequence generation)

      Problem: Each word that is output depends only on current hidden state, and not on previous outputs

      • The hidden activation at the <eos> âstoresâ all information about the sentence
      • The network actually produces a probability distribution over the output vocabulary: ykw=P(Ok=wâ£Okâ1,â¦,O1,I1,â¦,IN)y_k^w = P(O_k = w| O_{k-1},\dots, O_1,I_1, \dots,I_N)ykwâ=P(Okâ=wâ£Okâ1â,â¦,O1â,I1â,â¦,INâ)ï»¿
      • Objective: produce the most likely output (ends in an <eos>)

        â Greedy: select the most probable word at each time

        • Impossible to know a priori which word leads to the more promising future

        â Randomly draw a word at each
        time according to the output probability distribution

        • Not guaranteed to give you the most likely output
        • May sometimes give you more likely outputs than greedy drawing though

        # First run the inputs through the network

	[h(t),..] = RNN_input_step(x(t),h(t-1),...)

	[y(t),h_out(t)] = RNN_output_step(h_out(t-1), y_out(t-1))
	y_out(t) = argmax_i(y(t,i)) # sample(y(t)): if randomly sample from the output distribution.
until y_out(t) == <eos>
      • Problem: making a poor choice at any time commits us to a poor future
        • But we cannot know at that time the choice was poor
        • Solution: Retain only top K choices and fork the network to prevent it growing exponentially
        • Terminate path once output an <eos> â paths maybe different lengths
        ### Beam search
# Assuming encoder output H is available
path = <sos>
beam = {path}
pathscore = [path] = 1
state[path] = h[0]  # Output of encoder
do  # Step forward
	nextbeam = {}
	nextpathscore = []
	nextstate = {}
	for path in beam:
		cfin = path[end]
		hpath = state[path]
		[y,h] = RNN_output_step(hpath,cfin)
		for c in Symbolset
			newpath = path + c
			nextstate[newpath] = h
			nextpathscore[newpath] = pathscore[path]*y[c]
			nextbeam += newpath # Set addition
		end
	end
	beam, pathscore, state, bestpath = prune(nextstate,nextpathscore,nextbeam,bw)
until bestpath[end] = <eos>

### Pruning
# Note, there are smarter ways to implement this
function prune (state, score, beam, beamwidth)
	sortedscore = sort(score)
	threshold = sortedscore[beamwidth]
	prunedstate = {}
	prunedscore = []
	prunedbeam = {}
	bestscore = -inf
	bestpath = none
	for path in beam:
		if score[path] > threshold:
			prunedbeam += path # set addition
			prunedstate[path] = state[path]
			prunedscore[path] = score[path]
			if score[path] > bestscore
				bestscore = score[path]
				bestpath = path
			end
		end
	end
	return prunedbeam, prunedscore, prunedstate, bestpath
      • Training the networks
        • Forward pass:
          • Input the source and target sequences, sequentially (or by trick: input in reverse order)
          • Output a probability distribution over target symbol set (vocabulary)
        • Backward pass:
          • Compute the divergence
            between the output distribution and target word
            sequence
          • Backpropagate the derivatives of the divergence through the
            network to learn the net

          â Randomly select a single output y(t) and corresponding desired output d(t) for backprop

  • Multiple recurrent layer RNN
  • Bidirectional RNN - analyze data both ways (start â end, end â start) to make predictions (backprop follow the chain of recursion separately in the forward and reverse nets)
    # Subscript f represents forward net, b is backward net
# Assuming hf (-1,*) and hb (inf,*) are known
# x(t) is the input to the block (which could be from a lower layer)#forward recurrence

for t = 0:T-1 # Going forward in time hf
	(t,0) = x(t) # Vectors. Initialize hf(0) to input
	for l = 1:Lf
	# Lf is depth of forward network hidden layerszf
		(t,l) = Wfc(l)hf(t,l-1) + Wfr(l)hf(t-1,l) + bf(l)
		hf(t,l) = tanh(zf(t,l)) # Assuming tanh activ.
		#backward recurrence
		hb(T,:,:) = hb(inf,:,:) # Just the initial value

for t = T-1:downto:0 # Going backward in time
	hb(t,0) = x(t) # Vectors. Initialize hb(0) to input
	for l = 1:Lb
	# Lb is depth of backward network hidden layers
		zb(t,l) = Wbc(l)hb(t,l-1) + Wbr(l)hb(t+1,l) + bb(l)
		hb(t,l) = tanh(zb(t,l)) # Assuming tanh activ.

for t = 0:T-1 # The output combines forward and backward
	h(t) = [hf(t,Lf); hb(t,Lb)]
    # Inputs:
# L : Number of hidden layers
# Wc, Wr, b: current weights, recurrent weights, biases# hinit: initial value of h(representing h(-1,*))
# x: input vector sequence
# T: Length of input vector sequence
# Output:
# h, z: sequence of pre-and post activation hidden
# representations from all layers of the RNN
function RNN_forward(L, Wc, Wr, b, hinit, x, T)
	h(-1,:) = hinit # hinit is the initial value for all layersfor t = 0:T-1 # Going forward in time
	h(t,0) = x(t) # Vectors. Initialize h(0) to inputfor l = 1:L
	z(t,l) = Wc(l)h(t,l-1) + Wr(l)h(t-1,l) + b(l)
	h(t,l) = tanh(z(t,l)) # Assuming tanh activ.return h
    # Subscript f represents forward net, b is backward net
# Assuming hf(-1,*) and hb(inf,*) are known
# forward pass
hf = RNN_forward(Lf, Wfc, Wfr, bf, hf(-1,:), x, T)

#backward pass
xrev = fliplr(x) # Flip it in time
hbrev = RNN_forward(Lb, Wbc, Wbr, bb, hb(inf,:), xrev, T)
hb= fliplr(hbrev) # Flip back to straighten time

#combine the two for the output
for t = 0:T-1 # The output combines forward and backward
h(t) = [hf(t,Lf); hb(t,Lb)]

    Backpropagation

    • For forward net â Backpropagate âhf(t)Div\nabla_{h_f(t)} Divâhfâ(t)âDivï»¿ from ð¡=ðð¡ = ðt=Tï»¿ down to ð¡=0ð¡ = 0t=0ï»¿ in the usual way
      • Will obtain derivatives for all the parameters of the forward net
      • Will also get âX(t)Divforwardâ\nabla_{X(t)} Div_{forward} -âX(t)âDivforwardââï»¿ Partial derivative of the gradient for ð(ð¡)ð(ð¡)X(t)ï»¿ computed through the forward net
    • For backward net - Backpropagate âhb(t)Div\nabla_{h_b(t)} Divâhbâ(t)âDivï»¿ forward from t=0t=0t=0ï»¿ up to t=Tt=T t=Tï»¿
      • Will obtain derivatives for all the parameters of the forward net
      • Will also get âX(t)Divbackwardâ\nabla_{X(t)} Div_{backward} -âX(t)âDivbackwardââï»¿ Partial derivative of the gradient for ð(ð¡) computed through the backward net
    • âX(t)Div=âX(t)Divforward+âX(t)Divbackward\nabla_{X(t)} Div = \nabla_{X(t)} Div_{forward} + \nabla_{X(t)} Div_{backward} âX(t)âDiv=âX(t)âDivforwardâ+âX(t)âDivbackwardâï»¿
    # Inputs:
# (In addition to inputs used by L : Number of hidden layers
# dhtop: derivatives ddiv/dh*(t,L) at each time (* may be f or b)# h, z: h and z values returned by the forward pass
# T: Length of input vector sequence

# Output:
# dWc, dWb, db dhinit: derivatives w.r.t current and recurrent weights,# biases, and initial h.
# Assuming all dz, dh, dWc, dWr and db are initialized to 0

function RNN_bptt(L, Wc, Wr, b, hinit, x, T, dhtop, h, z)
	dh = zeros
	for t = T-1:downto:0 # Backward through time
		dh(t,L) += dhtop(t)
		h(t,0) = x(t)
		for l = L:1 # Reverse through layers
			dz(t,l) = dh(t,l)Jacobian(h(t,l),z(t,l))
			dh(t,l-1) += dz(t,l) Wc(l)
			dh(t-1,l) += dz(t,l) Wr(l)
			dWc(l) += h(t,l-1)dz(t,l)
			dWr(l) += h(t-1,l)dz(t,l)
			db(l) += dz(t,l)
			dx(t)= dh(t,0)
	return dx, dWc, dWr, db, dh(-1) # dh(-1) is actually dh(-1,1:L,:)
    # Subscript f represents forward net, b is backward net
# Given dh(t), t=0â¦T-1 : The sequence of gradients from the upper layer
# Also assumed available:
# x(t), t=0â¦T-1 : the input to the BRNN block
# zf(t), hf(t) : Complete forward-computation outputs for all layers of the forward net
# zb(t), hb(t) : Complete backward-computation outputs for all layers of the backward net
# Lfand Lb are the number of components in hf(t) and hb(t)

for t = 0:T-1 # Separate out forward and backward net gradients
	dhf(t) = dh(t,1:Lf)
	dhb(t) = dh(t,Lf+1:Lf+Lb)

#forward net
[dxf,dWfc,dWfr,dbf,dhf(-1)] = RNN_bptt(L, Wfc, Wfr, bf, hf(-1), x, T, dhf, hf, zf)

#backward net
xrev = fliplr(x) # Flip it in time
dhbrev = fliplr(dhb)
hbrev = fliplr(hb)
zbrev = fliplr(zb)
[dxbrev, dWbc,dWbr,dbb,dhb(inf)] = RNN_bptt(L, Wbc, Wbr, bb, hb(inf), xrev, T, dhbrev, hbrev, zbrev)
dxb= fliplr(dxbrev)

for t = 0:T-1 # Add the partials
	dx(t) = dxf(t) + dxb(t)

  • LSTM
    • Forward rule
    • Backward rule: backpropagate through an LSTM cell
    • ctc_tctâï»¿ is the linear history carried by the constant-error carousel
    • âForgetâ gate (ftf_tftâï»¿) determines whether to carry over the history or to forget it.
    • Do suffer from exploding gradient issue
    # Input:
# C : previous value of CEC
# h : previous hidden state value (âoutputâ of cell)
# x:  Current input
# [W,b]: The set of all model parameters for the cell
# These include all weights and biases
# Output:
# C : Next value of CEC
# h : Next value of h
# In the function:  sigmoid(x) = 1/(1+exp(-x))
#								   performed component-wise
# Static local variables to the cell 

static local zf, zi, zc, zo, f, i, o, Ci
function [C,h] = LSTM_cell.forward(C,h,x,[W,b])
	 zf = Wfc C+ Wfh h+ Wfx x + bf
	 f = sigmoid(zf) # forget gate
	 zi = Wic C+ Wih h+ Wix x + bi
	 i= sigmoid(zi) # input gate
	 zc = Wcc C+ Wch h+ Wcx x + bc
	 Ci = tanh(zc)  # Detecting input pattern
	 Co = fâC + iâCi # âââ is component-wise multiply
	 zo = Woc Co + Woh h+ Wox x + bo
	 o = sigmoid(zo) # output gate
	 ho = o â tanh(Co) # âââ is component-wise multiply
	 return Co,ho
    # Assuming h(-1,*) is known and C(-1,*)=0
# Assuming L hidden-state layers and an output layer
# Note: LSTM_cell is an indexed class with functions
# [W{l},b{l}] are the entire set of weights and biases
# for the lWo and both hidden layer are output layer weights and biases

for t = 0:T-1  # Including both ends of the index
	h(t,0) = x(t) # Vectors. Initialize h(0) to input
	for l = 1:L  # hidden layers operate at time t
		[C(t,l),h(t,l)] = LSTM_cell(t,l).forward(C(t-1,l),h(t-1,l),h(t,l-1)[W{l},b{l}])
	zo(t) = Wo h(t,L) + b
	Y(t) = softmax(zo(t))
    # Static local variables carried over from forward
 static local = zf, zi, zc, zo, f, i, o, Ci
 function [dC,dh,dx,d[W, b]] = LSTM_cell.backward(dCo, dho, C, h, Co, ho, x, [W,b])
	 # First invert ho = oâtanh(C)
	 do = dhoâ tanh(Co)T
	 d tanhCo = dho â o

	 dbo = dzo

	 dzf = df sigmoid(zf)T (1-sigmoid(zf))T
	 # Finally invert zf = WfcC+ Wfhh + Wfxx + bf
	 dC+= dzf Wfc
	 dh += dzf Wfh
	 dx += dzf Wfx
	 dWfc = C dzf
	 dWfh = h dzf
	 dWfx = x dzf
	 dbf = dzf
	 return dC, dh, dx, d[W, b]

     # Assuming h(-1,*) is known and C(-1,*)=0

  • Gated-RNN - simplify LSTM

Stability Analysis

  • Binary addition task: Add two N-bit numbers to produce a N+1-bit number
    • Input is binary

    MLP

    • Will require large number of training instances
      • Output must be specified for every pair of inputs
      • Weights that generalize will make errors â Network trained for N-bit numbers will not work for N+1 bit numbers

    RNN

    • Can add two numbers
      of any size
    • Needs very little training data

  • Time-delay structures have bounded output if â the function has bounded output for bounded input
    • Guaranteed if output and hidden activations are bounded
      • But will it saturate
    • What if the activation function is linear?

      where Hk(1t)H_k(1_t)Hkâ(1tâ)ï»¿ is the hidden response at time tttï»¿ with 000ï»¿ initial condition (can do similar thing for vector system).

      â It is sufficient to analyze hidden response at time t=0t=0t=0ï»¿ (if the system blows up at t=0t=0t=0ï»¿, it will blows up at t=1t=1t=1ï»¿)

      • Suppose hâ1=0h_{-1} =0hâ1â=0ï»¿, we have h0(t)=WhtWxx0h_0 (t) = W_h^t W_x x_0h0â(t)=WhtâWxâx0âï»¿
        • Write W=UÎUâ1âWui=Î»iuiW = U\Lambda U^{-1} â W u_i = \lambda_i u_iW=UÎUâ1âWuiâ=Î»iâuiâï»¿

      • Long-term behavior depends entirely on the eigenvalues of the recurrent weights matrix
        • If the largest eigen-value is greater than 1, the system will âblow upâ
        • If it is lesser than 1, the response will âvanishâ very quickly â Complex eigenvalues cause oscillatory response but with the same overall trends
        • Magnitudes greater than 1 will cause the system to blow up
    • Non-linear activation function analysis

    E.g. seeing a âclose bracketâ cannot affect RNNâs ability to predict an âopen bracketâ if it happened too long ago in the input

    Activations

    • Sigmoid activations saturate and the network becomes unable to retain new information
    • RELU activations blow up or vanish rapidly
    • Tanh activations are the slightly more effective at storing memory
      â But still, for not very long
Problem with training deep networks
  • MLP = nested function: Y=fN(WNfNâ1(WNâ1fNâ2(â¦W1X))))Y= f_N(W_N f_{N-1}(W_{N-1} f_{N-2}(â¦W_1 X))))Y=fNâ(WNâfNâ1â(WNâ1âfNâ2â(â¦W1âX))))ï»¿

    • As we go back in layers, the Jacobians of the
      activations constantly shrink the derivative

      â After a few layers the derivative of the divergence at any time is totally âforgotten.

      â WN,â¦,Wk+1W_N, \dots, W_{k+1}WNâ,â¦,Wk+1âï»¿ are identical for RNN

  • Repeated multiplication by the weights matrix will result in exploding or vanishing gradients.
    • Resulting in insignificant or unstable gradient descent updates - get worse as depth increases
    • The relation between X(0)X(0)X(0)ï»¿ and Y(T)Y(T)Y(T)ï»¿ is one of a very deep network â Gradients from errors at t=Tt=Tt=Tï»¿ will vanish by the time theyâre propagated to t=0t=0t=0ï»¿.
  • Can we replace âfi.Wi \nabla f_i . W_iâfiâ.Wiâï»¿ with something that will not blow up or fade?
    • Retain memories until a switch based on the input flags them as ok to forget
    • Or remember less
  • The constant error carousel

Language models (LMs)
  • LMs model the probability distribution of token sequences in the language
  • Can be used to
    • Compute the probability of a given token sequence
    • Generate sequences from the distribution of the language

Problem: Given a sequence of words (or characters), predict the next one

  • Represent words
    • Pre-specify a vocabulary of N words in fixed (e.g. lexical) order

    â represent each word by an NNNï»¿-dimensional vector (one-hot representation)

    • No assumption about relative importance and relationships between words

    â If properly learned, the distances between projected points will capture semantic relations between the word.

    • uses only NNNï»¿ corners of 2N2^N2Nï»¿ corners of a unit cube
    • (1,Ïµ,Î´)(1,\epsilon, \delta)(1,Ïµ,Î´)ï»¿ has no meaning except for Ïµ=Î´=0\epsilon = \delta = 0Ïµ=Î´=0ï»¿
    • Density of points =O(NrN)= \mathcal{O}\left(\frac{N}{r^N}\right)=O(rNNâ)ï»¿

    â very inefficient use of dimensions

    • Project to an MMMï»¿-dimensional subspace (M<<NM<<NM<<Nï»¿) WâPW\mathbf{W} â \mathbf{PW}WâPWï»¿

      Density of points =O(NrM) = \mathcal{O}\left(\frac{N}{r^M}\right)=O(rMNâ)ï»¿

  • Predicting words
    • Wn=f(W0,â¦,Wnâ1)W_n = f(W_0, \dots, W_{n-1})Wnâ=f(W0â,â¦,Wnâ1â)ï»¿

    â Dimensionality problem: all inputs W0,â¦,Wnâ1W_0, \dots, W_{n-1}W0â,â¦,Wnâ1âï»¿ are high-dimensional and sparse

    • The TDNN model:
      • Predict each word based on the past NNNï»¿ words â Hidden layer has tanh()tanh()tanh()ï»¿ activation, output is softmax.
      • Also learn low-dimensional
        representations of words
    • Soft bag of words: Predict word based on words in immediate context â Without considering specific position
    • Skip-grams: Predict adjacent words based on current word
  • Generating language: Synthesis
    • Feed the drawn word as the next word in the series â And draw the next word from the output probability distribution
    • Continue this process until we terminate generation

    <sos>: start of a sentence

    <eos>: end of a sentence

Transformer (L18, Nov 1 - L19, Nov 3)
  • Sequence â sequence (no time synchrony)
    • Question â response
    • Translate English â Spanish

    â Delayed sequence â sequence

    • Each word that is output depends only on current hidden state, and not on previous outputs
    • Input sequence feeds into a recurrent structure, terminated by an explicit <eos> symbol

  • Issues
    • Not sufficient to have the encoder hidden state to only the initial state of the decoder
    • Misses the direct relation of the outputs to the input
  • Simple solution
    • Compute the average of all encoder hidden states
      • But the average applies the same weight to every input

Attention Models

Use a different weighted average for each output word

  • ct=1NâiNwi(t)hic_t = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i}^N w_i(t) h_ictâ=N1ââiNâwiâ(t)hiâï»¿

  • The attention weights wi(t)w_i(t)wiâ(t)ï»¿ are dynamically computed as functions of decoder state wi(t)=a(hi,stâ1)w_i(t) = a(h_i,s_{t-1})wiâ(t)=a(hiâ,stâ1â)ï»¿
    • Expectation: if the model is well-trained, this will automatically âhighlightâ the correct input.
    • It captures the relative importance of each position in the input to the current output
    • Weights wi(t)w_i(t)wiâ(t)ï»¿ must be positive and sum to 111ï»¿
      • be a distribution
      • they must be high for the most relevant inputs for the i-th output and low elsewhere
      • Two step weight computation
        • ei(t)=g(hi,stâ1)e_i(t) = g(h_i,s_{t-1})eiâ(t)=g(hiâ,stâ1â)ï»¿

        • g(hi,stâ1)=hiTWgstâ1g(h_i,s_{t-1}) = h^T_i W_g s_{t-1}g(hiâ,stâ1â)=hiTâWgâstâ1âï»¿
        • g(hi,stâ1)=vgTtanhâ¡(Wg[histâ1])g(h_i,s_{t-1}) = v_g^T \tanh\left(W_g \begin{bmatrix}h_i\\ s_{t-1}\end{bmatrix}\right)g(hiâ,stâ1â)=vgTâtanh(Wgâ[hiâstâ1ââ])ï»¿

Query-Key-Value

Special case:

  • ki=vi=hik_i=v_i =h_ikiâ=viâ=hiâï»¿
  • qt=stâ1q_t = s_{t-1}qtâ=stâ1âï»¿
  • Encoder outputs âkeyâ (importance of the input at that time) and âvalueâ for a given output
  • Decoder outputs an âqueryâ (evaluate which inputs to pay attention to) at each output time

Pseudocode
# Assuming encoded input 
#   (K,V) = [k_enc[0] ... k_enc[T]], [v_enc[0] ... v_enc [T]] 
# is available
t = -1  # Initial Decoder hidden state
h_out[-1] = 0 # Initial query
q[0] = 0      

# Note: begins with a âstart of sentenceâ symbol
#       <sos> and <eos> may be identical
Y_out[0] = <sos>
do
	t = t+1
	C = compute_context_with_attention(q[t], K, V)
	y[t], h_out[t], q[t+1] = RNN_decode_step(h_out[t-1], y_out[t-1], C)
	y[t] = generate(y[t]) # Random, or greedy
until y_out[t] == <eos>
# Takes in previous state, encoder states, outputs attention-weighted context
function compute_context_with_attention(q, K, V)
	# First compute attention
	e = []
	for t = 1:T  # Length of input
		e[t] = raw_attention(q, K[t])
	end
	maxe = max(e) # subtract max(e) from everything to prevent underflow
	a[1..T] = exp(e[1..T] - maxe)   # Component-wise exponentiation
	suma = sum(a)  # Add all elements of a
	a[1..T] = a[1..T]/suma
	
	C = 0    
	for t = 1..T
		C += a[t] * V[t]
	end
	
	return C

Training Paradigm

  • Forward pass
  • Backward pass
    • Compute a divergence between target
      output and output distributions
    • In the early stages of training, output will be random.
    • Solution:
      • âTeacher forcingâ: passing in ground truth

        â This is cheating!!!

        â Problem: Decoder does not see
        ground truth labels during inference

      • Sampling the output to be input for some of the time
      • The âGumbel noiseâ trick: â Sampling is not differentiable, and gradients cannot be passed through itâ The âGumbel noiseâ approach recasts sampling as computing the argmax of a
        Gumbel distribution, with the network output as parametersâ The âargmaxâ can be replaced by a âsoftmaxâ, making the process
        differentiable w.r.t. network outputs

Extensions

  • Bidirectional processing of input sequence [Neural Machine Translation by Jointly Learning to Align and Translate, Bahdanau et al. 2016]
  • Local attention vs global attention [Effective Approaches to Attention-based Neural Machine Translation, Luong et al., 2015]
  • Multihead attention
    • Have multiple query/key/value sets
      • Each attention âheadâ uses one of these set
      • The combined contexts from all heads are passed to the decoder
    • Each âattenderâ focuses on a different aspect of the input thatâs important for the decode

Self-attention

Compute query-key-value sets for every word

  • Using the query for that word, compute attention weights for all words
    using their keys
  • Compute updated representation for the word as attention-weighted
    sum of values of all words

â this is a âsingle-headâ self-attention block

â âMULTI-HEAD ATTENTIONâ (actually Multi-head self attention)

â Multi-head self-attention block

â No need for recurrence!

!!! Didnât take distance between tokens into consideration !!!

Positional Encoding

â Add a âpositionalâ encoding to word embeddings to capture the relative distance from one another

where posposposï»¿ = index of token in the input sentence, iiiï»¿ = i-th dimension out of dmodeld_{model}dmodelâï»¿.

A sequence of vectors P0,â¦,PNP_0,\dots, P_NP0â,â¦,PNâï»¿ to encode position

  • Every vector is unique (and uniquely represents time)
  • Relationship between PtP_{t}Ptâï»¿ and Pt+ÏP_{t+\tau}Pt+Ïâï»¿
    only depends on the distance between them â enables the net to learn shift
    invariant âgapâ dependent relationship
    • never repeats
    • has the linearity property required
    • bounded

â MÏM_{\tau}MÏâï»¿ should be unitary & norm preserving

â unique encoding across dimensions

Transformer

  • âMaskedâ self-attention: forcing attention
    weights for embeddings at time
    t+1t+1t+1ï»¿ and later to be 000ï»¿.

A sequence-to-sequence model that replaces recurrence with positional encoding and multi-head self attention

Tremendous decrease in model computation for similar performance as state-of-art translation models

BUT!!!

  • Often require more parameters than LSTMs at equal performance
  • Tricky on small hardware (phones, IoT, etc.)
BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations)
  • Learn an effective representation that can be applied to a variety of downstream tasks?
    • Word2vec (2013)
    • GloVe (2014)
  • BERT Pre-Training Corpus:
    • English Wikipedia - 2,500 million words
    • Book Corpus - 800 million word
  • BERT Pre-Training Results:
    • BERT-Base â 110M Params
    • BERT-Large â 340M Params
  • BERT Pre-Training Tasks:
    • MLM (Masked Language Modeling)
    • NSP (Next Sentence Prediction)
  • BERT Fine-Tuning:
    • Simply add a task-specific module after the last encoder layer to map it to the desired dimension.
    • Classification Tasks:
      • Add a feed-forward layer on top of the encoder output for the [CLS] token
    • Question Answering Tasks:
      • Train two extra vectors to mark the beginning and end of answer from paragraph
  • BERT Evaluation:
    • General Language Understanding Evaluation (GLUE)
      • Sentence pair tasks
      • Single sentence classification
    • Stanford Question Answering Dataset (SQuAD)
  • Only uses encoder of transformer to derive word and sentence embeddings
  • Trained to âfill in the blanksâ
  • A form of representation learning

Pre-training tasks can be invented flexiblyâ¦

  • Effective representations can be derived from a flexible regime of pre-training tasks.
  • Different NLP tasks seem to be highly transferable with each other...
  • As long as we have effective representations, that seems to form a general model which can serve as the backbone for many specialized models.
  • And scaling works!!!
    • 340M is considered large in 2018

GPT (Generative Pretrained Transformer)
  • GPT Pre-Training Corpus:
    • Similarly, BooksCorpus and English Wikipedia
  • GPT Pre-Training Tasks:
    • Predict the next token, given the previous tokens
    • More learning signals than MLM
  • GPT Pre-Training Results:
    • GPT â 117M Params
    • Similarly competitive on GLUE and SQuAD
  • GPT-3: Generalizes to more tasks, not just more inputs!
  • Uses only the decoder of the transformer as an LMâ âTransformer w/o aux LMâ
  • Large performance improvement in many tasks
  • Add Task conditioning: put the nature of task in the input (not just LM)
    (Parameters x1000)
  • The Effectiveness of Self-Supervised Learning
    • The model seems to be able to learn from generating the language itself, rather than from any specific task we might cook up
  • Language Model as a Knowledge Base
    • A generatively pretrained model seems to have a decent zero-shot performance on a range of NLP tasks

And scaling works!!!

  • Divide your image in patches with positional encodings
  • Apply Self-Attention

Decoding

  • Greedy: pick the YtY_tYtâï»¿ with the highest probability
  • Top-K/ Top-p pruning
    • at each time, retain only the top-K (vocabs) or top-p (probability) scoring forks
    • Paths cannot continue once the output an <eos>
      â So paths may be different lengths

      â Select the most likely sequence ending in <eos> across all terminating sequences

  • Beam search
    • Slightly more efficient.
    • Does not perform redundant context computation
     # Assuming encoder output H = h[1]â¦ h
 [T] is available
 in
 path = <sos>
 beam = {path}
 pathscore = [path] = 1
 
 state[path] = h[0]  # initial state (computed using your favorite method)
 do  # Step forward
	 nextbeam = {}
	 nextpathscore = []
	 nextstate = {}
	 for path in beam:
		 cfin = path[end]
		 hpath = state[path]
		 C = compute_context_with_attention(hpath, H)
		 y,h = RNN_decode_step(hpath, cfin, C)
		 for c in Symbolset
			 newpath = path + c
			 nextstate[newpath] = h
			 nextpathscore[newpath] = pathscore[path]*y[c]
			 nextbeam += newpath # Set addition
		 end
	 end
	 beam, pathscore, state, bestpath = prune(nextstate,nextpathscore,nextbeam)
 until bestpath[end] = <eos>

Learning Representation

Non-linear separable data

â no hard linear classifier correctly separate the samples

â consider p(yâ£x)p(y|x)p(yâ£x)ï»¿, y={0,1}y=\{0,1\}y={0,1}ï»¿ rather than y=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x)ï»¿

  • Potentially more realistic

  • 1D example
    • At each point look at a small
      window around that point
    • Plot the average value within the windowâ This is an approximation of the probability of 1 at that point

    â sigmoid function

(linearly inseparable)

  • Given training data (X1,y1),â¦,(XN,yN)(X_1,y_1),\dots, (X_N,y_N)(X1â,y1â),â¦,(XNâ,yNâ)ï»¿, XXXï»¿s are vectors, yyyï»¿s are binary class values
  • Maximum likelihood estimation â\Leftrightarrowâï»¿ minimizing KL divergence between desired output yiy_iyiâï»¿ & actual output 11+eâyi(w0+wTXi)\frac{1}{1+e^{-y_i (w_0+\mathbf{w}^T X_i)}}1+eâyiâ(w0â+wTXiâ)1âï»¿

â no closed-form solution, need gradient descent

  • Consider separable case
    • For a âsufficientâ net, the final perceptron is a linear classifier

      (The rest of the network may be viewed as a transformation that transforms data from non-linear classes to linearly separable feature)

    • The data are (almost) linearly separable in the space of YYYï»¿
    • The network until the second-to-last layer is a non-linear function f(X)f(X)f(X)ï»¿
      that converts the input space
      XXXï»¿ into the feature space YYYï»¿ where the classes are maximally linearly separable.
    • For binary problems, using an SVM with slack at the final layer may be more effective than a final perceptron!
      • Option 1: First train the MLP with a perceptron at the output, then detach the feature extraction,
        compute features, and train an SVM
      • Option 2: Directly employ a max-margin rule at the output, and optimize the entire network

What do hidden layers learn?

  • Manifold hypothesis: For separable classes, the classes are linearly separable on a
    non-linear manifold
  • Layers sequentially âstraightenâ the data manifold â Until the final layer, which fully linearizes it

â affine transformation

The perceptron fires if the input is within a specified angle of the weight

  • Neuron fires if the input vector is close enough to the weight
    vector.
  • If the input pattern matches the weight pattern closely enough - i.e. If the input pattern and weight pattern are sufficiently correlated
  • The perceptron is a correlation filter!

âAutoencoderâ

= A neural network trained to predict the input itself

â Finds the direction of maximum energy

â In higher dimension without non-linear activations, it is still PCA.

  • Encoder learns to detect all the most significant patterns in the signals - The âAnalysisâ net which computes the hidden representation
  • Decoder recomposes the signal from the patterns - The âSynthesisâ which recomposes the data from the
    hidden representation

The simplest Autoencoder with a single hidden unit = PCA (All input vectors are mapped onto a point on the
principal axis, which minimize error)

x^=wTwx\hat{x} = w^T w xx^=wTwxï»¿

div(x^,x)=â£â£xâwTwxâ£â£2div(\hat{x}, x) = ||x - w^Tw x||^2div(x^,x)=â£â£xâwTwxâ£â£2ï»¿

âw^=argâ¡minâ¡E(â£â£xâwTwxâ£â£2)â \hat{w} = \arg\min \mathbb{E} (||x-w^T w x||^2)âw^=argminE(â£â£xâwTwxâ£â£2)ï»¿

  • With non-linearity â ânon-linearâ PCA
  • Deeper networks can capture more complicated manifolds
  • Examples
    • 2D spiral
      • 2 hidden layers of 100 neurons
      • not generalize beyond the manifold - extending hidden latent space beyond the values seen in training doesnât extend the helix
    • Signal separation (separating music): Given a mixed sound from multiple sources, separate out the sources
      • Any values applied to the (hidden) input to the decoder will produce data similar to the training data
      • Learn a dictionary of âbuilding blocksâ for each sound source
      • A mixed signal is the linear combination of signals from the individual sourcesâ Which are in turn composed of entries from its
        dictionary

Variational Autoencoder (VAE)

Want: model the distribution of any data - so that we can draw samples from it!

Some âsimpleâ generative model

  • PMF like Poisson distribution (parameter Î»\lambdaÎ»ï»¿)
  • Gaussian PDF (parameters Î¼,Î£\mu, \SigmaÎ¼,Î£ï»¿)

    âP(o)=â«P(x)dm=â«P(o,m)dmâ P(o) = \int P(x) dm = \int P(o,m) dmâP(o)=â«P(x)dm=â«P(o,m)dmï»¿

Expectation-Maximization (EM algorithm)
  1. Determine Q(x)Q(x)Q(x)ï»¿ that maximize the RHS, using current Î¸\thetaÎ¸ï»¿ (make the bound tight)
    • Solve âQ(h)RHS=0\nabla_{Q(h)} RHS = 0âQ(h)âRHS=0ï»¿, Q(h)â¥0Q(h) â¥ 0Q(h)â¥0ï»¿, âhQ(h)=1\sum_h Q(h) = 1âhâQ(h)=1ï»¿ if close form solution exists
    • If Q(h)Q(h)Q(h)ï»¿ is modelled by a NN, perform gradient descent with backpropagation.
    • For any P(h,o;Î¸)P(h,o;\theta)P(h,o;Î¸)ï»¿, the optimal Q(h)=P(hâ£o;Î¸)Q(h) = P(h|o;\theta)Q(h)=P(hâ£o;Î¸)ï»¿ (LHS = RHS)
      • Let Q(h)=P(hâ£o;Î¸â)Q(h) = P(h|o;\thetaâ)Q(h)=P(hâ£o;Î¸â)ï»¿, then

      logâ¡P(o;Î¸)â¥âhP(hâ£o;Î¸â)logâ¡P(h,o;Î¸)P(hâ£o;Î¸â):=J(Î¸,Î¸â)\log P(o;\theta) â¥ \sum_h P(h|o;\thetaâ) \log \frac{P(h,o; \theta)}{P(h|o;\thetaâ)} := J(\theta,\thetaâ)logP(o;Î¸)â¥âhâP(hâ£o;Î¸â)logP(hâ£o;Î¸â)P(h,o;Î¸)â:=J(Î¸,Î¸â)ï»¿

      â Note that logâ¡P(o;Î¸)=J(Î¸,Î¸)\log P(o;\theta) = J(\theta,\theta)logP(o;Î¸)=J(Î¸,Î¸)ï»¿

  1. Fix Q(h)Q(h)Q(h)ï»¿ and maximize the RHS w.r.t Î¸\thetaÎ¸ï»¿

â each step guaranteed to increase logâ¡P(o;Î¸)\log P(o;\theta)logP(o;Î¸)ï»¿, stop when logâ¡P(o;Î¸) \log P(o;\theta)logP(o;Î¸)ï»¿ stop increasing

Overall EM principle

  • Initially, some data/information are missing
  • Initialize model parameters
  • Iterate
    • Complete the data according to the posterior probabilities ð(ðâ£ð)ð(ð|ð)P(mâ£o)ï»¿ computed by the current model
      • By implicitly considering every possible value, with its posterior-based proportionality
      • Or by explicit completion through sampling the posterior probability distribution P(mâ£o)P(m|o)P(mâ£o)ï»¿
    • Re-estimate the model
PCA

Find the principal subspace such that when all vectors are approximated
as lying on that subspace, the approximation error is minimal
- Assuming âcenteredâ (zero-mean) data

  • Close-form solution exists

    Let âwLoss=0â(âxxTx)w=Î»w\nabla_w Loss = 0 â \left(\sum_x x^T x\right) w = \lambda wâwâLoss=0â(âxâxTx)w=Î»wï»¿ where Î»\lambdaÎ»ï»¿ is eigenvalue of the projection.

The estimation is scale invariant

  • We can increase the length of w, and compensate it by reducing z

Let Wâ=WB,Zâ=Bâ1(Z)Wâ = WB, Zâ = B^{-1}(Z)Wâ=WB,Zâ=Bâ1(Z)ï»¿, then WZ=(WB)(Bâ1Z)=WâZâWZ = (WB)(B^{-1} Z) = Wâ ZâWZ=(WB)(Bâ1Z)=WâZâï»¿, for arbitrary BBBï»¿ (a different set of bases for the same subspace)

  • The representation of the bases is not unique!
  • To make it unique, we can either

â constrain vectors in W to be unit length & orthogonal â standard âclosedâ form in PCA

â constrain the variance of Z to be unity

The iterative algorithm

  • Initialize a subspace (the basis wwwï»¿)
  • Iterate until convergence:
    • Find the best position vectors ZZZï»¿
      on the subspace
      WWWï»¿ for each training instance (complete the data with appropriate ZZZï»¿)
      • Find the location on WWWï»¿ that is closest to each instance, i.e. the perpendicular projection
    • Let W rotate and stretch/shrink, keeping the arrangement of ZZZï»¿ locations fixed (re-estimate WWWï»¿ given ZZZï»¿)
      • Minimize the total square length of the lines attaching the projection on the place to the instance
  • The linear AE can be constrained to give unique solution (i.e. variance of ZZZï»¿ is unity)

  • Generative story of linear AEs
    • Draw zzzï»¿ from a K-dim isotropic Gaussian (K = dim of the principal subspace)
    • A = PCA âbasisâ matrix (of principal eigenvectors, scaled by eigenvalues)
    • E = 0-mean & low-rank covariance Gaussian noise, orthogonal to principal subspace
    • If zzzï»¿ is Gaussian, X^\hat{X}X^ï»¿ is Gaussian
    • X^\hat{X}X^ï»¿ & EEEï»¿ are Gaussian â XXXï»¿ is Gaussian

    PCA assumes the noise is always orthogonal to the data

    • Not always true
    • Noise in images can look like images, random noise can sound like speech, etc.

    Factor Analysis (linear Gaussian model (LGM)):

    â generalize the model to permit non-orthogonal noise

    To generate any point

    • Take a Gaussian step on the hyperplane
    • Add full-rank Gaussian uncorrelated noise (diagonal covariance matrix) that is independent of the position on the hyperplane

    x=Az+Eâxâ¼N(0,AAT+D)x = Az + E â x\sim \mathcal{N}(0,AA^T+D)x=Az+Eâxâ¼N(0,AAT+D)ï»¿

    â The way to produce any data instance is no longer unique, though different corrections may have different probabilities

    • The probability density of x is Gaussian lying mostly close to a hyperplane - with uncorrelated Gaussian noise

The pipeline for VAE

â What about data that are not Gaussian distributed close to a curved or otherwise non-linear manifold rather than a plane?

f(z) is a non-linear function

  1. Find a function that warps a lower-dimensional input plane to the target manifold in the data space
  1. Transform a Gaussian distribution on the input plane to a distribution on the curved manifold
  1. Add some uncorrelated Gaussian âfuzzâ to account for off manifold variations

Issues:

  • Select (or guess) the dimensionality of the manifold
  • Choosing the right function f(z) that is capable of learning the shape of the manifold
  • EM for NLGM

    â zzzï»¿ is unobserved
