Diffusion & Flow (L23, Nov 20)

Given a data distribution pppï»¿ that is a mixture of two 2D gaussians as shown below in red. We want to approximate this with one gaussian estimate qqqï»¿ by minimizing KL-divergence DKL(pâ£â£q)D_{KL} (p||q)DKLâ(pâ£â£q)ï»¿

Diffusion model

Markovian Hierarchical Variational Autoencoder (MHVAEs) - with restrictions:

  • Latent dimension is the same as the data dimension
  • The encoder has no parameters to be learnt. It is defined to be a linear gaussian such that the ð¡-ð¡â gaussian is centered around the previous latent zð¡â1z_{ð¡â1}ztâ1âï»¿
  • The parameters for the gaussians are scheduled such that the final latent is a standard gaussian zTâ1â¼N(zT;0,I)z_{T-1} \sim \mathcal{N}(z_T;0,I)zTâ1ââ¼N(zTâ;0,I)ï»¿

Generative process

Diffusion Process (tractable)

  • Reconstruction: Reconstruction from least noisy version (hyperparameter choice can make this arbitrarily small)
  • Prior matching: Moving the posterior closer to the true prior on the final noisy step (0 for diffusion models)
  • Denoising: Divergence between approximate denoising (ðð) and true denoising (ð) steps

Normalizing Flows

(Maximize likelihood estimation)

  • z=g(x)z = g(x)z=g(x)ï»¿ determines where a point in x-space maps to z-space

âz=g1âg2ââ¯âgT(x)â z = g_1 \circ g_2 \circ \dots \circ g_T (x)âz=g1ââg2âââ¯âgTâ(x)ï»¿ =fâ1(x)= f^{-1}(x)=fâ1(x)ï»¿

Normally, compute determinant is O(n3),\mathcal{O}(n^3),O(n3),ï»¿ with n=n =n=ï»¿ dimension of the matrix, but only is O(n)\mathcal{O}(n)O(n)ï»¿ for triangular or diagonal matrix.

For a good (efficient) flow, we must have functions (steps) that are:

  1. Expressive
  1. Invertible
  1. Offer cheap to compute Jacobian determinants
  • Construction with a shuffle

    (to avoid x1x_1x1âï»¿ just passing along unchanged along the flow, still invertible by multiplying to a permutation matrix)

Coupling Flow â Used in implementations such as NICE and GLOW

  • E.g. GLOW
    • Multiscale architecture
    • Split along channels
    • Employ CNNs
    • Perform permutations using 1x1 Conv layers
GAN (L24, Nov 27 - L25, Dec 2)

Given a distribution of inputs X and labels Y

Explicit distribution models

  • Calculate P(xâ¼X)P(x\sim X)P(xâ¼X)ï»¿ for all xxxï»¿

Implicit distribution models

  • Generate xâ¼Xx\sim Xxâ¼Xï»¿

Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) (since 2014)

  • Generative Models which generate data similar to the training data.
    E.g. Variational Autoencoders (VAE)
  • Adversarial Training: two competing networks (adversaries) that are trying beat each other.
    • Generator input (latent vector) Z can be sampled from a known prior, e.g. standard Gaussian

Goal: PG(X)=PX(X)P_G(X) = P_X(X)PGâ(X)=PXâ(X)ï»¿, i.e. generated distribution matches true distribution

  • Generator is a VAE decoder
    • Maximizing the likelihood of the data

      Î¸â=argâ¡minâ¡âlogâ¡P(X;Î¸)\theta^* = \arg \min -\log P(X;\theta)Î¸â=argminâlogP(X;Î¸)ï»¿

    • Likelihood maximization does not implies whether the output actually looks like a real image (a face)

    â DILLAF loss (Discriminator)

    • Trainingâ¦
      • Discriminatorâs loss is backpropagated to the generator
      • Maximize the discriminator loss
        • {D(G(Z))=1,1âD(G(Z))=0 \begin{cases} D(G(Z)) = 1, \\1- D(G(Z)) = 0\end{cases}{D(G(Z))=1,1âD(G(Z))=0âï»¿
        • Minimize logâ¡(1âD(X^))\log (1-D(\hat{X}))log(1âD(X^))ï»¿ (want D(X^)=D(G(Z))=1D(\hat{X}) = D(G(Z))=1D(X^)=D(G(Z))=1ï»¿)
  • Discriminator is trained to tell the difference between real and generated (fake) data
    • If a perfect discriminator is fooled, the generated data cannot be distinguished from real data
    • Trainingâ¦
      • Inputs: training examples of real & synthetic faces
      • Minimize error between actual & predicted labels (classification loss)
        • D(X)={1,ifÂ XÂ isÂ real0,syntheticD(X) = \begin{cases} 1, & \text{if $X$ is real} \\0, & \text{synthetic}\end{cases}D(X)={1,0,âifÂ XÂ isÂ realsyntheticâï»¿
        • Maximize logâ¡D(X)\log D(X)logD(X)ï»¿ for real, logâ¡(1âD(X))\log (1-D(X))log(1âD(X))ï»¿ for synthetic.

GAN objective function

  • The perfect discriminator

    P(yiâ£X)=P(X,yi)P(X,y1)+P(X,y2)P(y_i|X) = \frac{P(X,y_i)}{P(X,y_1) + P(X,y_2)}P(yiââ£X)=P(X,y1â)+P(X,y2â)P(X,yiâ)âï»¿

    Perfect decision boundary is where P(X,y1)=P(X,y2)P(X,y_1) = P(X,y_2)P(X,y1â)=P(X,y2â)ï»¿

  • Updating the generator (fool the discriminator)

    â Moving the generator into the region assigned to the other class by the (perfect) discriminator

  • Iterativelyâ¦

Min-max Optimization

where JS(PX,PG)JS(P_X,P_G)JS(PXâ,PGâ)ï»¿ is the Jensen-Shannon divergence between PX(X)P_X(X)PXâ(X)ï»¿ and PG(X)P_G(X)PGâ(X)ï»¿.

  • Jensen-Shannon divergence
    • JS(P,Q)=12KL(P,12(P+Q))+12KL(Q,12(P+Q))JS(P,Q) = \frac{1}{2} KL\left(P,\frac{1}{2} (P+Q)\right)+ \frac{1}{2} KL\left(Q,\frac{1}{2} (P+Q)\right)JS(P,Q)=21âKL(P,21â(P+Q))+21âKL(Q,21â(P+Q))ï»¿ for probability distributions P,QP,QP,Qï»¿.
    • KL(P,Q)=âXP(X)logâ¡P(X)Q(X)KL(P,Q) = \sum_X P(X) \log\frac{P(X)}{Q(X)}KL(P,Q)=âXâP(X)logQ(X)P(X)âï»¿ blows up when Q(X)=0Q(X) = 0Q(X)=0ï»¿.
  • Stationary point
    • If PG(X)=PX(X)P_G(X) = P_X(X)PGâ(X)=PXâ(X)ï»¿ (global minima), D(X)=0.5D(X) = 0.5D(X)=0.5ï»¿ for all XXXï»¿ (i.e. discriminator converges)

    âââï»¿ âXD(X)=0\nabla_X D(X) = 0âXâD(X)=0ï»¿

    • This is also true of a random discriminator :(((
    • Stationary points need not be stable (depends on the exact GANs formulation and other factors)
      • Generator may overshoot some values or oscillate around the optimum
      • A discriminator with unlimited capacity can still assign an arbitrarily large distance to 2 similar distributions.
  • Generator and the discriminator need to be trained simultaneously
    • If discriminator is undertrained, it provides sub-optimal feedback to the generator
    • If discriminator is over-trained, there is no local feedback for marginal improvements
Pros & Cons

VAEs

  • Minimizing the KL divergence between distributions of synthetic and true data
  • Uses an encoder to predict latent
    distributions to optimize generator
  • More complex formulation
  • Simpler optimization. Trains faster and
    more reliably
  • Results are blurry

GANs

  • Minimizing the Jenson-Shannon
    divergence between distributions of
    synthetic and true data
  • Use a discriminator to optimize
    generator
  • Simpler formulation
  • Noisy and difficult optimization
  • Sharper results
  • âMode collapseâ are frequent - producing outputs with very low variability

Trainingâ¦

  • As the Discriminator gets more and more confident, the region that gives us informative gradients keeps shrinking.
  • No gradient information to further update the Generator after the Discriminator got too confident.
  • How to improve?
    • Consider the worst case: 2 distributions P and Q such that they are only 1 for 1 value of x and 0 otherwise. Let Î¸\thetaÎ¸ï»¿ be the distance between the peaks of these distributions.
      • KL(Pâ£â£Q)={0,Î¸=0â,Î¸â 0KL(P||Q) = \begin{cases} 0, & \theta =0\\ \infty, & \theta \neq 0\end{cases}KL(Pâ£â£Q)={0,â,âÎ¸=0Î¸î =0âï»¿
      • JS(Pâ£â£Q)={0,Î¸=0logâ¡(2),Î¸â 0JS(P||Q) = \begin{cases} 0, & \theta =0\\ \log(2), & \theta \neq 0\end{cases}JS(Pâ£â£Q)={0,log(2),âÎ¸=0Î¸î =0âï»¿

    â Wasserstein distance (WassersteinGAN)

    where Î\GammaÎï»¿ is the functional space that maps PXP_XPXâï»¿ to PGP_GPGâï»¿.

    Goal: Find the optimal mapping/ transport.

    • But unknown PXP_XPXâï»¿ & complex Î³\gammaÎ³ï»¿.

    Kantorovich-Rubinstein duality

    where â£â£fâ£â£Lâ¤1||f||_L â¤ 1â£â£fâ£â£Lââ¤1ï»¿ is set of 1-Lipschitz scalar functions.

    â Clipping to make fffï»¿ 1-Lipschitz

    1. Update D(Î¸D)D(\theta_D)D(Î¸Dâ)ï»¿ using gradient of EX[D(x)]âEZ[D(G(z)))]\mathbb{E}_X [ D(x)] - \mathbb{E}_Z[ D(G(z)))] EXâ[D(x)]âEZâ[D(G(z)))]ï»¿
    1. Clip all the weight in Î¸D\theta_DÎ¸Dâï»¿ to some [âc,c][-c,c][âc,c]ï»¿
    1. Update G(Î¸G)G(\theta_G)G(Î¸Gâ)ï»¿ to maximize EZ[D(G(z)))]\mathbb{E}_Z[ D(G(z)))] EZâ[D(G(z)))]ï»¿

    • If the clipping parameter is too large, then it takes too long to train the Discriminator to optimality.
    • If too small, then the gradients vanish before reaching the generator.

    â Gradient penalty

    • Push the norm of the gradient to be close to 1

    â Spectral norm

    • Enforce the Lipschitz constraint on the weights

      where Ï(Wl)\sigma(W_l)Ï(Wlâ)ï»¿ is the spectral norm of weight WlW_lWlâï»¿.

    • The Lipschitz norm (the bound) for a composite function (NN) is upper bounded by the product of the Lipschitz norms of the composing functions (each layer).

Various versions

High fidelity natural images
(2019)

â High Resolution

StarGAN (2018)

â Better quality

  • Wasserstein GAN
  • StarGAN - Image-to-image translation

    Discriminator:

    1. Identify whether an image is fake or not.
    1. Predict the target domain of the input image.
      • Uses an auxiliary classifier to learn the mapping of original image and its corresponding domain from the dataset

    Generator:

    1. The images generated are realistic.
    1. The images generated are classifiable as target domain by D.
    1. Able to reconstruct the original image from the fake image given the original domain label. (Cycle consistency Loss)
  • Conditional GAN

    with class yyyï»¿ associated with the input data and latent vectors.

    • Provides more control in what type of images are generated by the generator
    • Are not strictly unsupervised learning algorithms because they require labeled data as input to the additional layer
    • Able to generate the outputs for exactly the classes or labels that we desire

  • LapGAN (Laplacian GAN)
    • A chain of conditional GANs, to generate progressively larger images.
    • A conditional GAN generates larger images conditioned on the smaller image, repeated
      until you reach the desired size.
  • BiGAN
  • CycleGAN
    • Autoencoder alternative

    â CycleGAN

    • Cycle consistency loss (just a reconstruction loss)
      • Ensures that the generated image has retained enough information about the input enough to retrieve it using a different âspecial purposeâ generator
    • Image translation / Style transfer
    • For specific and small no. of images
    • Need a content and style image
    • Specific & small number of images

    • Just need 2 domains of images. No need for specific content or style
      images
    • Many similar pictures
    • Specificity of images doesnât really matter
  • DCGAN

etc.

Hopfield Network

Analogy: Spin Glasses

  • Magnetic diploes in a disordered magnetic material
  • Total field at current dipole:

where pip_ipiâï»¿ is vector position of iiiï»¿-th dipole

  • Each dipole tries to align itself to the local field â in doing so it may flip
  • This will change fields at other dipoles - which may flip â changes the field at the current dipoleâ¦
    • Response of current dipole
  • The field at any dipole is the sum of the field contributions of all other dipoles
  • The contribution of a dipole to the field at any point depends on interaction â Derived from the âIsingâ model for magnetic materials (Ising and Lenz, 1924)
  • The âHamiltonianâ (total energy) of the system
    • The system evolves to minimize the energy (could be at local minimum)
    • Dipoles stop flipping if any flips result in increase of energy

â Consider a loopy network (Hopfield Net)

  • At each time each neuron receives a âfieldâ
  • If the sign of the field matches its own sign, it does not respond
  • If the sign of the field opposes its own sign, it âflipsâ to match the sign of the field

  • Each neuron is a perceptron with +1/-1 output
  • Every neuron receives input from every other neuron
  • Every neuron outputs signals to every other neuron

yiââyiy_i â -y_iyiâââyiâï»¿ if yi(âjâ iwjiyj+bi)<0y_i(\sum_{j\neq i} w_{ji} y_j+b_i) <0yiâ(âjî =iâwjiâyjâ+biâ)<0ï»¿

â But this may cause other neurons to flip!

Q: Will this behavior continue for ever??

  • Let yiây_i^{-}yiââï»¿ and yi+y^{+}_iyi+âï»¿ be the output of the iiiï»¿-th neuron just before and after it responds to the current field, respectively.

  • Energy of a Hopfield net
    • The evolution of a Hopfield network constantly decreases its energy (until some local minimum).
      • For threshold activations the energy contour is only defined on a lattice â so yyyï»¿ are corners of a unit cube
      • For tanh activations it will be a continuous function (output in [â1,1][-1, 1][â1,1]ï»¿)
      • âEnergyâ contour for a 2-neuron net
        • Two stable states (tanh activation)

          â Symmetric, but not at corners

        • Blue arc shows a typical trajectory for tanh activation
      • âEnergyâ contour for a 3-neuron net
        • 8 possible states
        • 2 stable states (for hard thresholded network)
    • Each of the minima is a âstoredâ pattern (stable state) = content addressable memory / associative memory (recall memory content from partial or corrupt values)
      • How do we make the network store a specific pattern or set of patterns?

        â How do we teach a network to ârememberâ an image with N pixels?

        • Every neuron connects to every other neuron

        • Need to estimate WWWï»¿ such that EEEï»¿ is minimized for target patterns YP={y1,y2,â¦,yP}\mathbf{Y}_P = \{\mathbf{y_1} ,\mathbf{y_2} ,\dots, \mathbf{y_P} \} YPâ={y1â,y2â,â¦,yPâ}ï»¿ and maximized for any other yâÌ¸YP\mathbf{y} \not\in \mathbf{Y}_Pyî âYPâï»¿.
        • Simple gradient descent
          • Do we need to raise everything?
            • If you raise every valley, eventually theyâll all move up above the target patterns, and many will even vanish

            â Focus on raising the valleys

            • Major requirement: memories must be stable (must be broad valleys)
            • Spurious valleys in the neighborhood of memories are more important to eliminate
          • What if thereâs another target pattern downvalley?

            â Raising it will destroy a better-represented or stored pattern!

            • No need to raise the entire surface, or even every valley
            • Raise the neighborhood of each target memory
              • Sufficient to make the memory a valley
              • The broader the neighborhood considered, the broader the valley
        • How do we increase the capacity of the network?

          where in hidden neurons, actual values are not important!

          â Randomly: Flip a coin for each bit

          • We could even compose multiple extended patterns for a base pattern to increase the probability that it will be recalled properly
          • Recalling any of the extended patterns from a base pattern will recall the base pattern

          â May have multiple hidden patterns for a target pattern (multiple valleys, in which the visible bits remain the same, but hidden bits vary)

A probabilistic interpretation of Hopfield Nets

  • For binary y\mathbf{y}yï»¿, the energy of a pattern = negative log likelihood of a Boltzmann distribution
    • The Boltzman distribution P(y)=Cexpâ¡(âE(y)kT)P(\mathbf{y})= C \exp \left( \frac{- E(\mathbf{y})}{kT}\right)P(y)=Cexp(kTâE(y)â)ï»¿
      • kkkï»¿ is the Boltzmann constant
      • TTTï»¿ is the temperature of the system
      • C=1âyexpâ¡(âE(y)kT)C = \frac{1}{\sum_{\mathbf{y}} \exp \left( \frac{-E(\mathbf{y})}{kT}\right)}C=âyâexp(kTâE(y)â)1âï»¿.
    • The system probabilistically selects states with lower energy - with infinitesimally slow cooling, at T=0T=0T=0ï»¿, it arrives at the global minimal state.
    • Selecting a next state = drawing a sample from the Boltzmann distribution at T=1T=1T=1ï»¿, in a universe where k=1k=1k=1ï»¿.
  • Minimizing energy â\Leftrightarrowâï»¿ maximizes log likelihood
  • Optimizing WWWï»¿ using GD

    where Î±y\alpha_{\mathbf{y}} Î±yâï»¿represents the weight for more frequently presented memories, Î²(E(y))\beta(E(\mathbf{y}))Î²(E(y))ï»¿ represents weight to more attractive spurious memories.

  • The Helmholtz Free Energy of a system
    • A thermodynamic system at temperature TTTï»¿ can exist in one of many states
      • Potentially infinite states
      • At any time, the probability of finding the system in state sssï»¿ at temperature is PT(s)P_T(s)PTâ(s)ï»¿
    • At each state sssï»¿, it has a potential energy EsE_sEsâï»¿
    • The internal energy (capacity to do work) of the system is the average
    • The capacity to do work is counteracted by the internal disorder of the system, i.e. its entropy
    • The Helmholtz free energy of the system combines the two terms

      â A system held at a specific temperature anneals by varying the rate at which it visits the various states, to reduce the free energy in the system, until a minimum free-energy state is achieved.

      â The probability distribution of the states at steady state is known as the Boltzmann distribution.

      â Minimize FTF_TFTâï»¿ w.r.t PT(s)P_T(s)PTâ(s)ï»¿, we get PT(s)=1Zexpâ¡(âEskT)P_T(s) = \frac{1}{Z} \exp \left(\frac{-E_s}{kT} \right)PTâ(s)=Z1âexp(kTâEsââ)ï»¿

      • Known as the Gibbs distribution
      • ZZZï»¿ is a normalizing constant
      • Note the dependence on TT Tï»¿
      • At T=0T = 0T=0ï»¿, the system will always remain at the lowest energy configuration with probability = 1.
  • The stochastic Hopfield network models a probability distribution over states = Boltzmann machine (a generative model) generates states according to P(S)P(S)P(S)ï»¿
    • Deterministic Hopfield network: learn weights to ârememberâ target states and âdislikeâ other states (âStateâ SSSï»¿ == binary pattern of all the neurons)
    • Boltzmann machine: learn weights to assign a desired probability distribution to states
    • The parameters of the model are the weights of the network
    • The probability that (at equilibrium) the network will be in any state is P(S)P(S) P(S)ï»¿

    • Models a Boltzmann distribution
    • logâ¡P(S)=âE(S)+C\log P(S) = - E(S) + ClogP(S)=âE(S)+Cï»¿

    • The field at a single node
      • Let SSSï»¿ and SâSâSâï»¿ be identical states (y1,â¦,yi,â¦,yN)(y_1, \dots, y_i, \dots, y_N)(y1â,â¦,yiâ,â¦,yNâ)ï»¿ that only differ in the iiiï»¿-th bit

        i.e. suppose yi={1,yiâSâ1,yiâSây_i = \begin{cases} 1, & y_i \in S \\-1, & y_i\in Sâ\end{cases}yiâ={1,â1,âyiââSyiââSââï»¿

      where E(S)=â12(Eâ i+âjâ iwjiyj+bi)E(S) = -\frac{1}{2} \left(E_{\neq i} + \sum_{j\neq i} w_{ji} y_j + b_i \right)E(S)=â21â(Eî =iâ+âjî =iâwjiâyjâ+biâ)ï»¿,

    • Evolution of a stochastic Hopfield net

      â Let the system evolve to âequilibriumâ

      • Let y0,â¦,yL\mathbf{y}_0, \dots, \mathbf{y}_Ly0â,â¦,yLâï»¿ be the sequence of values
      • Final predicted configuration: from the average of the final few iterations
        • If the probability that yi=1y_i = 1 yiâ=1ï»¿ is greater than 0.50.50.5ï»¿, sets yi=1y_i =1yiâ=1ï»¿
      • Include a temperature term in computing the local field to improve the likelihood of finding good (or optimal) minimum-energy state
        • At T=âT = \inftyT=âï»¿, the energy âsurfaceâ will be flat.
        • At T=1 T = 1T=1ï»¿, surface will be the usual energy surface.
        • At T=0T = 0T=0ï»¿, we get deterministic Hopfield behavior.
  • Training the Boltzmann machine = maximize likelihood of stored states

    where states S=(y1,y2,â¦,yN)S = (y_1, y_2, \dots, y_N)S=(y1â,y2â,â¦,yNâ)ï»¿âS \in \mathbf{S}âSï»¿

    • We cannot compute the exact value of (2)(2)(2)ï»¿ since it is summed over all training states, but we can estimate it via sampling!
    • How do we draw samples from the Boltzmann distribution?
      • Initialize the network randomly and let it âevolveââ probabilistically selecting state values according to our model
      • After many many epochs, take a snapshot of the state
      • Repeat this many many times
      • Let the collection of states be Ssim={Ssim,1,â¦,Ssim,M}\mathbf{S}_{sim} = \{S_{sim,1},\dots, S_{sim,M}\}Ssimâ={Ssim,1â,â¦,Ssim,Mâ}ï»¿

      â gradient ascent of the weight using the sampled likelihood estimate

  • Training the Boltzmann machine with hidden neurons
    • S=(V,H)S = (V,H)S=(V,H)ï»¿ where V=V =V=ï»¿ visible bits, H=H =H=ï»¿ hidden bits
    • We are interested in the marginal probabilities over visible bits
      • Want to learn to represent the visible bits
      • The hidden bits are the âlatentâ representation learned by the network
  • Train a network to maximize likelihood of desired patterns of visible bits
    • Repeat K times to generate synthetic training data
      • For each training pattern ViV_iViâï»¿, fix the visible units to ViV_iViâï»¿
        • Let the hidden neurons evolve from a random initial point to generate HiH_iHiâï»¿
        • Generate Si=(Vi,Hi)S_i =(V_i,H_i)Siâ=(Viâ,Hiâ)ï»¿
    • Unclamp the visible units and let the entire network evolve several times to generate
    • Applications
      • Filling out patterns
        • âAnchorâ the known visible units
        • Let the network evolve
        • Sample the unknown visible units & choose the most probable value
      • Denoising patterns
      • Computing conditional probabilities of patterns
      • Classification!!

        Training patterns: [s1,s2,â¦,Â class][s_1, s_2, \dots, \text{ class}][s1â,s2â,â¦,Â class]ï»¿

        • Features can have binarized or continuous valued representations
        • Classes have âone hotâ representation

        â Given features, anchor features, estimate a posteriori probability distribution over classes (or choose most likely class)

    • Issues
      • Training takes for ever
      • Doesnât really work for large problems (only works well on a small number of training instances over a small number of bits)

      â Restricted Boltzmann machine (RBM)

      Recall Boltzmann machine:
      • Still obeys the same rules as a regular Boltzmann machine
      • But the modified structure adds a big benefit.
      • Excellent generative models for binary (or binarized) data

      Visible units only talk to hidden units

      Hidden units only talk to visible units

      Other variants:

      • Continuous-values RBMs

        P(vi)=r(yi)expâ¡(yi)P(v_i) = r(y_i) \exp(y_i)P(viâ)=r(yiâ)exp(yiâ)ï»¿

      • âDeepâ Boltzmann machines
      • Helmholtz machine (trained by the âwake-sleepâ algorithm)

      â Training RBM

      • No looping!!
      • For each sample, iteratively sample hidden and visible units for a long time (anchor visible units and samples from hidden units, then repeat vice versa)
      • Draw final sample of both hidden and visible unit
Towards Rapid Design of Dexterous and Agile Robotic Behavior

(Guest lecture: Pulkit Agrawal, MIT)

  • How to design behaviors for complex task in less structured settings (such as robots)?
    • succeed in understanding (e.g. need a sponge to clean the spill) - common sense knowledge from LLMs
    • failed in low-level execution (e.g. use the sponge to clean the spill itself) â donât have enough data
  • Designing robot behaviors is not scalable

Goal: how to quickly and easily design diverse & complex behaviors that work in less structured settings?

  • Manipulation (e.g. grasping objects) - no motions between objects & fingers
  • Automating hands - need frequent & breaking of contacts between objects & fingers
    • Continuous-discrete optimization â hard to solve/ slow inference
    • Main challenge when design controller for tasks beyond grasping
      • Made simplifications: simple object shapes or smaller motion range

      â restricted finger motion (easier optimization but lack of generality)

â want: general orientation system with complex shapes & generalizable

Dexterous manipulation

  • Simulations to Reality is a powerful paradigm for contact-rich tasks.

An integrated design pipeline for tactile sensing robotic manipulators [Zlokapa et al., ICRA 2022]

Why does agile locomotion in the wild remain challenging?

  • Anticipating the future

â Solution:

  • Sub-optimal model approximation
    • Reduced order model in MPC
    • Simulation to reality gap in learning methods

    E.g. not possible to sprint fast & spin fast at the same time
